TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Why did he mislead the Parliament in his answer to the honourable member for Hughes on 12 February 1986?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. I say by way of preface on this issue, because there has been a great deal of discussion in the media about the safety of defence procedures that have been in place for a very long time, having regard to the whole debate on the Auditor-General's report and, in this specific instance, the answer to this question raised by the honourable member for Hughes some two years ago, that we have been discussing moving from a safe standard to a very safe standard and that all answers and discussion on this ought to be taken from that perspective.

ANSWER.PARA: I made inquiries of my Department when those Press stories appeared over the weekend, seeking a full report on the circumstances and advice surrounding the answer to the question that was subsequently submitted to me. I have received that report from the Secretary to my Department and I accept its conclusions. The first is that the answer to the question was not inaccurate. The question related in the first instance specifically to Army storage requirements and that qualified the remainder of the questions. The answer to those questions was accurate. Evidence of that fact is that it is always open to members on both sides of the House, once a question has been answered, if they feel it ought to be broadened out or more things answered, to ask further questions. No further questions were asked in this instance, as might be expected. The honourable member for Hughes has a very specific concern with the question of Army storage dumps as they exist within his electorate.

Where the problem arose evidently was that in devising that advice there was a discussion among officers of the Department on whether they ought to broaden out the answer to the question. In the course of that discussion by minute to each other they expressed themselves in a manner which I consider totally inappropriate. But that does not alter the nature of the answer to the question that ultimately emerged which I am satisfied was an accurate answer to what was asked. Of course, that is the obligation that is on me in answering questions in this House. Apropos the honourable gentleman's question on this matter, the problem with which the Department has been wrestling since 1981-he allegedly wants to tarnish me with taking no notice of things that are happening in my Department-arose from a decision to proceed to these standards in 1981 which was not advised to Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Treasurer inform the House of the effects of reregulation of the Australian economy on our potential for growth of long term economic security?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the five years that this Government has been in office we have increasingly opened Australia up to the winds of international competition. Back in 1983 we as a government consciously decided that having tried the closed way for 40 years and watched Australia's standard of living decline there was no other recourse but for Australia to go the open way of launching itself with the rest of the world. That started principally by opening Australia up by the removal of exchange controls and then floating the exchange rate, having our exchange rate set in the market. We have fashioned since a dynamic financial sector by removing exchange controls; we have restored primacy of the banking system by abolishing deposit maturity controls; and we have increased competition in that sector by the entry of foreign banks.

ANSWER.PARA: Beyond that sector we have sensibly addressed the issue of protection and the problem of key industries, particularly in steel and in motor vehicles, and we have steadily commercialised government business enterprises by winding back needless regulations. We are in the course of ending the two-airline policy. In the wages area we have fostered the right climate for industry, at the enterprise level, bargaining for efficiency gains. In virtually every nook and cranny of the economy we have faced up to and dealt with impediments to economic growth caused by needless and burdensome overregulation. These are all achievements which this Government alone has had the courage and the capacity to deliver. They are the things which were ignored on the other side of the House in the Fraser-Howard years.

There is an issue outstanding where success has been only partly achieved and that is in respect to media law. In media law, as in other areas of the economy that I have just mentioned, the Government sought to open up the media of this country. That was occasioned by the Australian satellite, which has meant that the technology shift has been the factor which has determined the Government's policy on media law. That is, the satellite gave the capacity to television proprietors to deliver to rural and provincial Australia all of the services that were available in the capital cities. To do that the Liberal and National parties' two-station rule, which was imposed by Prime Minister Menzies to advantage particular proprietors in the past, had to go because in the aggregated zones the people in rural and provincial Australia who were to benefit from the satellite technology could not so benefit while ever the two-station rule applied.

To take advantage of the satellite and to take advantage of the capacity to aggregate these zones so that we could give people in rural Australia better television, give them the right to watch everything that is watched in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and elsewhere, we as a government decided to remove the two-station rule and to put in its place an extended capacity of television ownership, but with one great distinction from anything the Liberals might have done. We have said that if people are in television they cannot be in print in the same places, under the cross-media rule. This decisive cross-media rule puts us in a position to allow sensible networking in television whereby a television proprietor, having been frozen out of the print media, could develop a national television network. That was to be accomplished by allowing an audience reach of enough capacity to network all of the capital cities plus a regional zone. That was encompassed within the Government's 75 per cent legislation-that is, 75 per cent of the audience reach of one network-bearing in mind that with three television networks, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service, there is a 500 per cent audience reach.

Because of the crazy behaviour of the Opposition in the Senate last week it is now not possible to network the capital cities. This is an issue of debate and it has come back to the Parliament for discussion. In a deliberative discussion among the Opposition front bench last week to consider what principle they should apply to this one area of commerce in Australia, when the Government has made clear what principle it applies to the rest of commerce in Australia, they said, `We are in the box seat here. We will get the Democrats to support us in the Senate. What will we do?'. They decided that they would go back to a bit more regulation, as they have always done. It is a trip back down the time tunnel to 1949 and 1951-the halcyon days of Menzies and McEwen and father knows best. The Opposition front bench is saying, `We know what is best for you because we are the Party of business and we have our stoolies on the company boards. We know and we will tell you what you will have. You will not be able to run a market forces philosophy. You will not be able to deliver television to country people because we will tell you that you cannot operate a television network'.

When asked what the basis of this decision is they say, `We are not going to be told by the Government to accept some number it picks'. They are saying that 75 per cent is as good as 60 per cent. The fact is that there is a world of difference, otherwise there would not be an issue, because at 75 per cent we can network the whole country and run a sensible television group and we can allow major proprietors to deliver television to country people. I know that the Opposition does not want country people to get television from the capital cities. That is what it is about. Basically, the Opposition has it in for the country people and it has damned them to one television station. It does not want to give rural Australia three television networks.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations, arises from the number of options being considered in the community in connection with the development of wages policy. Will the Minister bring us up to date, clarify the position and explain the progress being made in discussions between the Government, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and employer organisations in the development of wages policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been discussions between the Government, the ACTU and employer organisations in recent days on wages policy, and also there will be discussions in the next week or two. I am not able to disclose the full details of those meetings but I can say that there is agreement between the parties that the wages system should continue to provide a positive impetus for a more productive economy. That is a very welcome level of agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, with the second tier system, we have for the first time a wages system which is providing positive inducement to increased productivity. It is also agreed that although the second tier has had that effect the parties generally agree that it needs to be changed. The unions are concerned about the lack of access, with only 50 per cent of wage and salary earners under awards having received a second tier increase at this stage, and employers generally wanting to have a wider menu of options under that second tier principle. There is also recognition that award restructuring can provide substantial productivity gains in the future.

Unions have also flagged their concern that the process of real wage decline should come to an end. This is clearly more possible in the context of falling inflation, which, as honourable members would be aware, is anticipated to be around 6 per cent by the end of this financial year and, as the Treasurer has recently indicated, should be around 5 per cent by mid-1989-perhaps less. The Government has indicated also in these discussions that a relevant factor in wages outcome is the rate of increase in wages in our competitor countries. For this reason the rate of increase in wages in Australia must be constrained to present levels or less.

As a result of these and further discussions we will be having, we are confident that this country will continue to have a wages policy which will be conducive to economic recovery and to restructuring and that as we go into the May review we will have a lot of agreement towards that end. The past performance of the Government would give confidence that that would be the case because, as everyone in this House is aware, the reality is that wages policy has been one of the more spectacular areas of success for this Government. We have been able to achieve, by agreement, a remarkable change in the wages system in this country, with a reduction in the rate of increase in nominal wages to almost half the rate of increase which applied under the previous Fraser Government. We have also achieved a reduction in the real level of wages of 7 per cent and in real unit labour costs of 10 per cent. Those, of course, were difficult reductions to achieve in the sense that they were difficult for the parties involved, but they were not difficult for the economy as a whole because they were achieved by agreement. They were achieved by the Government and the unions agreeing to the basis of our wages policy and convincing the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that the policy should be implemented. Had there been no such agreement, clearly such necessary wages policy changes could have been achieved only by a massive depression of the economy to bring about the much lower level of wage increases. That would have been extremely difficult to achieve.

I am very interested to note that in today's Melbourne Herald the honourable member for Goldstein has acknowledged that on wages the Opposition could not have done as well as the Government has done. He said:
I frankly am in no doubt that the wages outcome which has been delivered so far by the Government could not have been achieved by a coalition Government, even-
he added-
if I had been Industrial Relations Minister.

That statement by the honourable member for Goldstein is absolutely correct. There is no way that the Opposition could have achieved the wages outcome which this Government has achieved, because it could never have achieved it by agreement. The only alternative was to attack the economy in a way which would have required large increases in unemployment, and had the Opposition achieved the wages outcome, it would have been at great economic and social cost, as all members of the Opposition know. We are confident that wages policy will continue on the path which this Government has set it on; that is, that it will be conducive to economic recovery, to the restructuring of this country, and that it will continue to be a major success for this Government.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts and Territories. Following questions in this House last week, has the Minister instituted any further inquiries about the recommendation that Dr Geoff Caldwell lead the social impact study team for the Australian Capital Territory casino?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Caldwell was appointed to head the social impact study following a recommendation from my Department and the National Capital Development Commission. The Department based the recommendation on an evaluation of his career and his achievements and on the high regard in which he is held in the Australian Capital Territory community. Dr Caldwell, for the information of the House, is the head of the Australian National University (ANU) Centre for Continuing Education. He has held various posts at the ANU over the past 20 years and has acted as a consultant to a variety of Australian and international institutions. I am informed that he is an acknowledged independent expert on gambling studies.

ANSWER.PARA: Following an inquiry by the Opposition last week about `Dr Caldwell's past and present associations with the gambling industry', I directed the Department to re-examine its earlier advice to me. The Secretary to the Department, Mr Tony Blunn, and other senior officials met with Dr Caldwell late last week. I am advised that Dr Caldwell referred to his involvement over the last decade in a range of debates in various States on gambling issues. In particular, I am advised that he described the nature of his participation in the campaign by the Licensed Clubs Association of Victoria in relation to poker machines in that State from about 1979 to 1982. These events have been canvassed in the report of the Inquiry into Poker Machines in Victoria, known as the Wilcox report, which was published in 1983. Dr Caldwell indicated that he had had discussions with and had appeared at seminars during that campaign with a Mr Vibert. I am advised that Mr Vibert was actively involved in the campaign for poker machines by the Licensed Clubs Association of Victoria and that Dr Caldwell participated in that campaign. I am also now aware that Mr Vibert was later charged with criminal offences, I think in New South Wales, but I am advised that on appeal the prosecution case was not successful.

I understand that Dr Caldwell has informed my Department that his association with Mr Vibert and his role in this campaign and before the inquiry were those of an independent academic expert on these issues. I am advised further that he has stressed that, apart from payment for expenses and what he described as the going rate for speaking fees, he received no other remuneration for this activity. I am advised further that he has apparently appeared from time to time in a number of forums in most States.

Mr Blunn has advised me that he believes that, on the information available, there is no evidence to call into question Dr Caldwell's appointment to the inquiry or to question the original advice given by the Department and the National Capital Development Commission. Dr Caldwell was chosen to lead the casino social impact study because of his acknowledged expertise in gambling studies and his professional reputation. I conclude by saying that, if any honourable member has any more to say or any specific thing to say on this matter, I suggest that he say it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did notice a rather fascinating interview which the Leader of the Opposition gave on the subject of foreign affairs to the Australian newspaper. ANSWER.PARA: I find it necessary to put that down first because if we are to engage in this interesting little exercise of `show me your statistics and I will show you mine', I will show the Leader of the Opposition that I have bigger statistics than he has. I'm not quite sure I've thought through the formula.

They shouldn't demand of those who say things that, well, you tell me exactly what is going to occur. Well, I'm not going to. I haven't worked it out in my own mind.

He has certainly got plenty of room to move these things around, backwards and forwards and sideways and up and down, without having any sort of collision. When asked whether he would see greater Japanese spending in a military sense concentrated in the north Pacific or down here, he said:

These are the two resources of greatest wisdom on these matters in the Opposition. The honourable member for McPherson has as much authority on defence as a half-pay admiral from the Swiss Navy. Of course, we all have a dear affection for the honourable member for North Sydney. His doleful visage reminds us all of a basset hound on holiday from a Pal pet food advertisement on television. The interviewer had to remind him that his own Government supported the introduction of the Rimpac naval exercises which involved Japan. I think if we are going to have this silly sort of comparison-`I have been there more times than you have been there'-the Opposition comes off second best because my record throughout the Asian-Pacific area shows up better than that of my predecessors.

But it is scarcely a real challenge. For instance, the honourable member for Kooyong, whom I have referred to before in this House as having been a distinguished Foreign Minister of this country, and I refer to him as such again, would not have been to, for instance, Thailand or Indonesia as frequently as I have, but he would have met those people frequently at multilateral forums, as I have met the Foreign Ministers for Japan, Korea or China in those countries, but more frequently at multilateral forums. I really think that we need to get foreign policy down on to a substantial basis for discussion and not some sort of flimsy response from the Leader of the Opposition when he says:
Don't press me on the detail. I just don't want to get into it . . .
That really is redolent of Bjelke-Petersen at his worst.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The incompetence displayed by the Minister for Defence in the administration of his department.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance relates to the administration of the Department of Defence by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I want to start on the handling and storage of defence ammunition and on the fact that the Minister, despite what he said today and the fact that he tried to blame his Department, has misled this Parliament. Whether he had been misled by someone else is irrelevant. He is the Minister and he has misled the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: He admits that the answer to the question from the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) in 1986 was not complete. It was not complete; it was a deliberate falsehood because the departmental officers who handled that question set out deliberately to give a misleading answer to the Minister. As one departmental source is reported to have said, `It was a slimy attempt to avoid telling the truth'. That is the sort of department he runs. So there is no question that the Minister misled the Parliament. The question by the honourable member for Hughes on 23 April 1985 asks:
. . . Are there schools and other public institutions within these NATO zones; if so, where and how many. . . Is there public or private housing within these zones; if so, where and what amount.
Ten months later-the question having gone round and round the Department no doubt while officers worked out how they were going to give the answer-the answer was tabled by the Minister. It states:
No public institutions or private housing are affected on account of their location within zones established by the NATO principles in proximity to Army ammunition dumps.

The Department deliberately-and these comments are on paper-said, `We will only talk about Army, that way we will keep it clean. We certainly will not talk about the Navy or the Air Force because we will be in trouble'. Does the Minister accept responsibility for that or does he not? If he does not, how can he say that he is running a department? How to frame this reply was openly discussed in the Department. The Department said, `Will we feed the Minister this line or will we feed him that line?'. The matter of giving the Minister the truth to the question was not considered at all. Obviously, the Minister is being treated as a child or as a fool by this Department. He is certainly being insulted because his Department is regarding him as irrelevant.

The attitude by the Department of Defence raises some very interesting questions. Why is the Department giving the Yes Minister treatment to this Minister for Defence? Why is it not telling him the truth? How is it that departmental officials are openly discussing what line of misinformation they will feed their Minister? How can they commit such comments to paper? The reason is that the Department is simply not taken seriously by the Minister for Defence. It regards him as a man with an obsessional interest in equipment and in nothing else-not in his Department, not in the 70,000 men and women whom he nominally commands-except big equipment items. So it treats him accordingly. What is the use of giving him any information if he is not interested in running the Department? It is common knowledge in the Department that this is the Minister's approach, so his officers naturally please themselves about what they will do, how they will treat matters and what they will serve up to him. Part of this is caused by the fact that over the years he has completely rejected their advice.

The paper by the chiefs of the Services on wastage in early 1987 was given to the Minister. It said that the Services had a problem. Until the middle of 1987 the Minister said in this House time and time again that there was no problem in the Services. He ignores his chiefs of the Services. The report by the Hamilton Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses is supposed to fix up all the problems of service families. It was 18 months before one recommendation was implemented. The PC9 trainer is now coming into service against the advice of the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). The Minister knows best. He will have the PC9 trainer and now the RAAF has to reorganise the whole of its training cycle to accommodate his new trainer. On 21 April there was another equivocal answer given in this House. The Minister said about ammunition storage:
. . . now no permanently inhabited area on Sydney Harbour remains within the prescribed safety distances.

What does the Minister mean by that? Does that mean that there are areas where people go that are not permanently inhabited but the people are in danger? I ask the Minister to clarify that. I also ask the Minister: Has the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) been in touch with the former Premier of New South Wales about this matter? Did he know that there were areas of Sydney that did not conform to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) standards? Has he, the Prime Minister, tried to circumvent the very guidelines that he, the Minister, is trying to implement within his Department? Again the Minister said in here that the situation is obviously undesirable but it is not unsafe. What does that mean? Is it possible to be undesirable but not unsafe? Is it safe or is it not? Is he implementing the guidelines? The Minister is also on record as saying that it is impossible to completely comply with the guidelines. The whole situation is a mess and we hope, for the safety of people who live around these ammunition depots, that this afternoon the Minister will clarify the situation. How can it be safe when it does not comply with the NATO guidelines? When will all the depots be brought up to scratch? What will be the cost to implement these standards? On how many other occasions has information been withheld from the Minister? How many public risk waivers has the Minister now signed and when did he sign them? Why should we ever trust anything the Minister says in this place again?

I turn briefly to another major area of maladministration: namely, the enormous wastage rates occurring in the Services because 70,000 men and women, who look to the Minister, as their nominal commander, for leadership and guidance, are flocking out of the Services in record numbers month after month. The Minister has failed to take any responsibility for their welfare. He concentrates on his equipment projects, three of which are now in disarray. That is the irony of the situation: even the things he concentrates on he cannot do properly. The treatment of Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel is a disgrace-it is not only incompetence; it is neglect, ignorance and arrogance. The Minister is presiding over the dismemberment of the Australian Defence Force. The security shield that we rely on around this country is gravely weakened. Our capacity to influence events in our region of interest is almost non-existent. The Minister has displayed no interest in or knowledge or understanding of the people he commands. He comes forward with academic views on defence and ignores the most important resource of all, the people who are supposed to make it work. In the last three years he has lost over one-third of the people he commands-27,000 people have left the Services. I did not spend 21 years in the Army to come into this Parliament and see the Minister dismember the Australian Defence Force. We intend to keep pressure on the Minister and his Government until they take some action to do the right thing by the people who serve the Minister and this country.

The Minister said today that we should look at America; it has a problem. We are not interested in the American problem; we are interested in what the Minister intends to do for the service men and women of Australia. Let us look quickly at some of the wastage figures. Between 1984 and 1987, through the Minister's own direct efforts, he reduced the Services by 2,000. In 1983 we lost 6,500 people from the Australian Defence Force; in 1987 we lost 9,113. In three years we have lost 27,000, which is 42 per cent-that is in three years-of the trained force of 63,000 in the Australian Services. In January this year a record 1,200 people left the Australian Defence Force and in February another 800 left. In two months of this year, 2,000 people left. If that rate is projected over one year it comes to 12,000, which would mean that 17 per cent would leave in one year. By comparison, the United Kingdom wastage rate is less than 5 per cent. The Army, for example, has lost 11,200 men in the two years to July and was 421 officers short at the last count. A system which cannot meet the replacements means that the shortage will increase by 60 a year. One hundred and seventy-seven lieutenant-colonels have resigned in the last 15 months; 62 of them have held unit command. How does one replace that sort of experience? Ninety-eight of them have been to a staff college. Only 9 per cent of the Australian Army now has been in active service. One simply cannot replace that experience that is daily leaving the Army in particular. The debilitating effect on the Army is destroying the force as we have known it. The saddest story of the lot is the RAAF. I simply do not have time to go into that. These are not just my views. Let me quote briefly a submission from General O'Donnell, the Chief of the General Staff, to the parliamentary committee on wastage which is now sitting and which we set up through the Senate because the Government would not act. He said.
High wastage in the Army is of major concern and has the potential to pose significant long term consequences for national Defence.
He went on to refer to `the deleterious effect on Army capability', and said:

Current wastage levels cannot be tolerated without detriment to capability . . . Operational Deployment Force is under strength . . . skeletal levels of manning in lower priority units with resultant loss of capability . . . infantry battalions (not in ADF) required to operate at 71 per cent of their complement . . . reduction in the number of quality officers not available for promotion . . . adverse effect on management and leadership.

General Jeffries, the commander of the 1st Division, has repeatedly asked for more men-up to 4,000 men. He said that we cannot sustain the Division in the field for any length of time. I very much doubt that we can sustain even one battalion in the field for a matter of weeks. So the story goes on-through the Navy, the Air Force and the whole of the Defence Force.

Wherever we turn the glorious empire the Minister sees himself heading, with the great academic views on what we should be doing about defence, is falling apart. His departmental administration is a shambles, with officers busy asking themselves whether they will tell the Minister something or give him certain information or misinformation day by day. The neglect of personnel has resulted in a record exodus from the Defence Force. Shipbuilding projects are in trouble throughout the country. He has now been caught misleading the Parliament, for which he accepts no responsibility whatsoever. There is a witch-hunt in his Department to find out who is shafting him. When a Minister gets into trouble in this House it is always someone else's fault and we will hear the same thing today. He has been given false information. He is failing to administer his Department and the best thing that can happen is for him to resign so that we can get on with the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The calls of the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) for my resignation would have been more sensibly received by the general public if they did not come at the rate of about three or four a week, which is the current performance of the confetti of ill-expressed, ignorant Press releases he dumps on the Press Gallery, about one in four of which get something of a minor run. Those Press releases repeat most of the nonsense he has dumped on us here today. In the time available to me only some of that nonsense will be capable of being dealt with. By way of background I start as I did in answer to the question he raised with me in Question Time. After all this nonsense about the impact of wastage rates, the developments in defence industry and equipment programs is dumped on us, all this crisis that he presents, he said, `I am going overseas where my top priority for study will be nuclear-powered warships'. God help us! So that is his view of the seriousness of his role as the shadow Minister for defence. He has put up a totally pathetic performance.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall cover one or two things that display the genuine ignorance of the Press releases he puts out-for example, on the completion of the frigate project and the signing of tenders at this stage. He put out a Press release today which repeated what he had to say here today along the lines that the project was now out of schedule, that we had not managed to sign up the companies. That was the implication of the question he put down. This totally ignored the fact that last week we put out several Press releases, which got coverage, saying that we had signed the tenders with Australian Warship Systems and Australian Marine Engineering Corporation Consolidated. They have been signed, they are operating and everything is proceeding to schedule. That demonstrates that the shadow Minister simply does not comprehend the changes that are going on in the shipbuilding industry as a result of our defence policy initiatives.

That there should be teething problems and difficulties, to anyone who was not a complete ignoramus, would be obvious. We have never done things like this before. We have always operated, as the previous Government operated when contractual obligations were entered into for ship construction here, on cost plus bases. Companies are now obliged to take an element of risk. Obviously, companies entering into this sort of situation, a project potentially worth $5 billion, want to give it a bit of thought. That they might wander around the place every now and then working out whether they want to stay in the project in these sorts of circumstances is entirely understandable. The only thing that is not understandable is why the shadow Minister does not understand it.

The second element of the proposition goes to my alleged obsession with equipment. Right at the heart of the issues of the efficiencies of the Office of Defence Production and the Defence Logistics Organisation have been the policies of this Government, picking up on years of neglect by honourable members opposite when in office. The reason for the $200m savings we are now getting in the factories and the reason we can now reorganise the Defence Logistics Organisation, which, incidentally, is the outfit around which this debate originated, is that since I have been Defence Minister I have been struggling, for about the first time any Defence Minister has done so, with the real industrial issues that our Department raises and the real inefficiencies in the Department. The report to me by the Secretary to the Department on the matter which generated this debate, which I will table when I have finished speaking, states:

This matter and the manner of its handling by officials raises the question of competence of administration with the Defence Logistics Organisation. I remind you of our discussion about 9 months ago when you expressed dissatisfaction with the performance of that Organisation.

He then goes on to tell us how it has been changed. It is because, as Defence Minister, I have been struggling to get to grips with these situations that we are able to contemplate the possibility of savings. The shadow Minister neglects entirely the fact that this situation grew like Topsy under his Government and was never addressed. He asks me why in three years as Defence Minister I have not achieved absolutely everything. I am sorry about that. It takes a bit of time to get $200m worth of savings out of the factories. It takes a bit of time to get the Defence Logistics Organisation of the Department right. We have had about three years to confront it, and it is not right yet. It will not be right for some considerable time because, when practices have been built up over the years under honourable members opposite, there is obviously a requirement systematically to review things from the bottom up. That has been going on.

The Opposition simply does not comprehend how to make defence policy. One does not start with the bits and pieces at the sides of defence policy and mount criticisms from there; one goes to strategy. One relates force strategy to force structure and relates force structure to the funds that are available. Nowhere has there been an Opposition policy developed on this. I saw the honourable member answering questions on television when the Auditor-General's report came down dealing with the problems we have in implementing the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) standards, of which those opposite were ignorant as Ministers, although when they were in government those standards were adopted around the country. The honourable member was obviously coached by the interviewer, Peter Young, on Channel 10. He said, `When you lose manpower you diminish safety'. I can just see him up there being coached by Peter because Peter likes his answers short-Peter's parrot Peter. The Auditor-General's report is not about manpower; it is about facilities and the location of facilities. If the honourable member reads through it he will see that. But that was the honourable member's view. The report came down and he thought, `Oh, it must be related to manpower'. But it is related to facilities. What does he have to say about facilities?

We had something to say about facilities in the last election. In the last election campaign he looked at our proposition to shift the Navy to Jervis Bay, which, incidentally, is intimately bound up with one of the most substantial problems that we confront in the area we are discussing, and at our proposition to shift it across to Western Australia and get it out of Sydney. The Navy should not be in Sydney. It should be in either Jervis Bay or Western Australia. We are not going to be able to change that in the next few years, but we are working at it. The honourable member took a look at these propositions and said, `Perhaps we can slow down in these facilities areas so we can spend a bit more in one or two other areas'. That is fine, but he should not come into this place when we have, front and centre, a facilities problem here that will require additional expenditure on facilities and tell us that he knows something about it and that his comments have been relevant to the situation we confront. He is totally irrelevant to this defence debate. He has proved it again in the remarks he has made here today.

The honourable member asked me a series of questions about specific details-what standards have been achieved, what waivers should be offered and the like. We have made some changes in standards of operation in Sydney Harbour. He asked whether these related to permanent or impermanent activities. I have been under pressure in regard to one of those impermanent activities, specifically the Sea Cadets associated with one of the islands in Sydney Harbour, that can materially be affected by this--

TALK.START.PARA: —Snapper Island.

—Snapper Island. As I have said, I have been under pressure to ignore the standards that ought to be applied in relation to it because there is no substantial danger to the personnel involved and therefore the standards ought not to be implemented. I accept that point of argument. We can look at the activities associated with our defence establishments and find that in many areas it will be a perfectly safe operation with a waiver of the NATO standards. This is a very complex area, a very complex issue. When under the previous Government-its Ministers were ignorant of them-the Department decided that the NATO standards should be implemented, there was no clear cut understanding of what costs would be involved, of what would be required in terms of waivers or what would be a realistic timetable. The honourable member does not have to take my word for that, he can read the Auditor-General's report. That is what he said. We have been struggling with the consequences of that ever since. SPEECH.PARA: The answer that was given to the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) was not misleading. It came from a constituency with an Army base in it. TALK.START.PARA: —I have had questions on notice for six months.

—Nothing has come forward apart from those questions asked by the honourable gentleman who has just interjected, which he will eventually get an answer to. SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member got on to the PC9 trainer program. He suggested that I was misled by my Department and then criticised me for allegedly overruling a part of it on the PC9 training. But let me tell honourable members that we had to make that decision largely because the trainer aircraft replacement program considered by our predecessors when they were in office was considered on the basis of faulty information about when the CT4 was going to go out of service. They now have a remuneration tribunal in which they can have their conditions arbitrated like any other members of the Australian work force. The fact of the matter is that in Australia over the last few years people have had to take cuts in living standards. That has affected the community; it has affected the defence forces less.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I make is that the honourable member for McPherson always has a wish list of expenditures which are not attached to any budgetary requirement. On the one hand he argues for massive increases in equipment-nuclear ships, or whatever-and on the other hand we have the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), saying that we have to get some $11 billion or $13 billion out of the system. The honourable member for McPherson has been very responsible in raising these matters and in further highlighting them here today. His actions have been vindicated by those words of the Auditor. The Minister has failed to ensure proper procedures in the giving of a reply to a question on notice. He has failed in administering his Department and in administering the new system which the former Minister for Defence, the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), brought into being and which I am sure the Minister was briefed about when he became Minister for Defence in December 1984. No action concerning public risk waivers was taken until July 1987. In fact, the Minister would have been briefed that eight locations plus another five locations were going to require public risk waivers under these safety guidelines for ammunition dumps around Australia. It is a chilling situation that in fact the Minister was misled on this matter and that by his own resources he was not able to detect that misleading. It is a chilling situation that the Parliament and the nation as a whole have been misled on this fundamental issue.

The wastage of experienced personnel in our defence forces adds further to this chilling situation. It is legitimate for us to consider that in this debate and when we look at the statistics involved. I would like to quote from a document that has not fallen off the back of a truck; it is a legitimate submission of the Royal Australian Navy to a Senate committee investigating wastage. It says:
There is clear evidence that within the Department of Defence the existing departmental machinery is inadequate to cope with the need to view these items within reasonable timescales. . . .
Some conditions of service matters have been held up in the system for long periods, . . .

It goes on to analyse the Hamilton report on the effect of service life on spouses, produced in 1986. The submission states that the overall wastage rate in the Navy is running at 12.6 per cent. The committee report stated in relation to that that of greater consequence than the average wastage rate are the wastage rates of middle ranking officers and technical sailors which are of major concern to Navy and bear directly on the successful attainment of Navy's medium term aims. We have a Navy that is bleeding slowly to death in terms of its experienced personnel; likewise the Army and the Royal Australian Air Force. The naval establishment shortfall in seamen lieutenants is 23 per cent, in engineer lieutenant commanders it is 45 per cent, and in communications radio operators-a fairly necessary manning requirement, as I am sure the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) and other honourable members would point out-it is 41 per cent. This horrible situation goes directly to the responsibilities of the Minister for Defence as the overall senior Minister who is in charge of coming up with the right mix of government policies and priorities to ensure we retain an adequate, competent, experienced and capable defence force.

The Minister has failed in that he has presided over the worst period of wastage in the Navy, Army and Air Force in years. He has failed in areas that are directly available to the Government to rectify. Let me refer briefly to one of those areas, coming under one of the Minister's two junior Ministers in cohesion, Ministers in some form or arrangement under his portfolio jurisdiction. I refer, of course, to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys).

I refer to the chopping and changing of the defence service home loan scheme. They have had about four goes at arriving at the right defence service home loan scheme. All the Government has done is chop back the maximum period of loan from 32 years to 25 years. Have not our soldiers, sailors and airmen the right to expect a defence service home loan? Have they not the right, after all their transfer postings in their careers, to take out a loan and build a house with some commitment? The maximum term has been reduced from 32 years to 25 years. I will concede that the Government has introduced portability, but at the same time it has abolished the $10,000 grant alternative.

There are four key charges against this Minister at this time. Why did he or his ministerial office fail to double-check the reply to the question with notice from the honourable member for Hughes? Why was there nine months delay? Why did the Minister not get on top of proceedings for that very key question with notice? And why did he accept the snowing by his Department, by those two departmental officers, of the provision of the proper information to him, to the Parliament and to the nation? That is the first charge. The second charge is: why did the Minister or his ministerial office fail to follow up the whole issue of public risk waivers, which was originally notified-in effect signed-in late 1984, which saw no action until the first public risk waiver came forward in July 1987? The Minister should have heard warning bells ringing loud and clear with regard to the massive delays. He is taking actions now-too little, too late, and only as a consequence of what the Opposition has put up.

The other areas are: why is the Minister dealing with the Government policies and priorities which are leading to the massive wastage and allowing the unions to run riot in terms of delaying some of the submarine contracts?

TALK.START.PARA: —And their safety.

—Exactly-and their safety, as the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel just said. SPEECH.PARA: A lot of people might dismiss the Hamilton report as an interesting document and not think too much about it, but I assure the House that many people in this country believe that it is a most significant report, because this is the first time attention and recognition has been given to defence families. Mrs Hamilton travelled around Australia and spoke to the wives and husbands of personnel of the defence forces about their difficulties and problems. She returned to Canberra, compiled a report and in due course the Minister tabled that report. It has been claimed that that procedure took a long time. TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, I present the fourth and the fifth reports for 1988 relating to the following proposed work:

SPEECH.PARA: Construction of new Commonwealth offices, Melbourne; and construction of new Commonwealth offices, Haymarket, New South Wales.
Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In accordance with the Government's policy of increasing its ownership of office accommodation and thereby reducing rental outlays from high priced central city locations, the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works has recommended the construction and fitout of two new Commonwealth office buildings, one in Melbourne on the corner of Spring and Lonsdale Streets at an estimated cost of $118m for construction and $18m for fitout and the other in Sydney at the Haymarket on the corner of Pitt and Hay streets at an estimated cost of $143m for construction and $20m for fitout, all at April 1987 prices.

SPEECH.PARA: The new Commonwealth offices in Melbourne will be a 42-storey building consisting of a nine-storey podium and a 33-storey tower. The building will provide 60,000 square metres net of office space to accommodate some 4,000 staff and include shopfront accommodation for departments with a high level of public contact.

The site for the building is portion of a larger Commonwealth owned block bounded by Spring, La Trobe, Exhibition and Lonsdale Streets. Other developments proposed for this block are stage two of the Commonwealth offices building and new offices for Telecom. The block is being developed as an integrated whole even though development is planned in stages. As the block has not been redeveloped since it was acquired by the Commonwealth in 1948, an archaeological investigation was undertaken on the block. The Department of Administrative Services and Telecom each provided $50,000 for the archaeological salvage project on the block.

A number of heritage buildings located on the perimeter of the new Commonwealth offices site will be retained and preserved by the Commonwealth. However, none of the heritage buildings form part of the development proposal. The Committee has recommended further consultation between the Department of Administrative Services and the Victorian Ministry for Planning and Environment concerning the future of the heritage buildings.

The design solution for the new Commonwealth offices at the Haymarket, Sydney, has evolved from complex site conditions and planning criteria. The design solution incorporates a 31-storey office tower to the south of the site, a nine-storey wing to the west of the site with a two-storey podium to the north-east. The building will provide 50,000 square metres net of office space to accommodate some 3,000 staff and approximately 1,600 square metres net of retail-commercial space including shopfront space for the Commonwealth. Three historic buildings and an underground gas holder base will be restored and have been integrated into the development. The building has been designed specifically in harmony with the heritage character of the Haymarket area and the scale of the surrounding streetscape particularly along Hay and Pitt Streets. The Department of Administrative Services has consulted with the Australian Heritage Commission on heritage issues and will continue to do so as conservation work is documented in detail. The National Trust of Australia and the Heritage Council of New South Wales will also be involved in those consultations to take advantage of their particular expertise.

During the Committee's investigation of the proposal, planning and heritage groups expressed concern about the overshadowing of Belmore Park and Eddy Avenue to the east of the site by the tower development. After examining all of the issues, the Committee concluded that the Department of Administrative Services had examined a range of design options and that almost any viable building on the Haymarket site would produce some overshadowing of Belmore Park and Eddy Avenue irrespective of the design solution. The Public Works Committee is satisfied that the Department of Administrative Services has developed a design that keeps overshadowing to a minimum while providing an economically viable building for the Commonwealth. The proposed office buildings will generate savings on Commonwealth office accommodation rental and lead to an improved overall standard of Commonwealth office accommodation with consequent improvements in operational efficiency and a reduction in operating costs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we resume debate on the Admiralty Bill 1988. Debate on the Bill commenced last week and, due to time constraints, was adjourned. At that stage I had already indicated the Opposition's view on this Bill, which is to support it, and I am very pleased to reiterate that support for this measure. I will very briefly put the matter into context. The Bill arises out of a very good report from the Australian Law Reform Commission which included a draft Bill. That draft Bill has been virtually totally adopted by the Government in introducing the Bill which we have before us today. In my opening remarks I canvassed the need for reform and gave a general outline of the Bill. I commenced to make some comments on some of the details of the Bill, initially with remarks concerning surrogate ships. I want to pick up my remarks in regard to jurisdictional issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill proposes that admiralty jurisdiction in rem be conferred concurrently on the Federal Court of Australia and State and Territory supreme courts. Inferior or intermediate courts may be proclaimed as courts having in rem jurisdiction where it is appropriate to do so. Although no estimate has been made of the extent of business which will be initiated after this Bill has become law, we do know that between 1974 and 1983 the courts have handled an average of 140 cases per annum in this jurisdiction. The options were to give all of the jurisdiction to the State and Territory supreme courts, leave the jurisdiction to the High Court of Australia and the supreme courts of the States and Territories, give all of the jurisdiction to the Federal Court or, as apparently was suggested by Mr Justice Zelling in the 1960s, establish a separate Federal Court devoted to admiralty and maritime matters.

The Liberal Party's policy for the last election, which I expect will remain as coalition policy, is to recognise that the High Court is the pinnacle of our legal system. As such I accept the proposition that it is more appropriate for the Federal Court to have the original jurisdiction than to have the High Court hearing matters at first instance. Appeals to the High Court should be by special leave. As was noted, the volume of admiralty business has not been large. I would not expect it to grow considerably, even given the reforms contained in this legislation.

The Law Reform Commission's report canvasses some of the wider issues in regard to jurisdiction. Those arguments are not new. One can go back as far as the 1920s when the late Sir Owen Dixon, arguably Australia's most eminent jurist, recommended that we should have an integrated court system. That system would be neither State nor Federal but would encompass the whole body of law, regardless of its source. The debate on that proposal has gone back and forward over the years. We have had numerous discussions at various Constitutional Conventions. Certainly the recent cross-vesting legislation has been one of the consequences of those discussions.

I say as an aside that people in the Government are very fond of saying that there has been very little constitutional development over the years when they look at the number of referendums. But if one knows anything about constitutional reform one will understand that issues such as cross-vesting, which have arisen out of those debates and have found their way onto the statute books, are in themselves part and parcel of the process of constitutional reform. There is obviously much merit in the concept of integration, but I think the political reality in Australia is that integration will not be achieved with the stroke of a pen. Although there are contrary arguments, in my view it would require a constitutional amendment. I do not think that one could be confident about the success of such a referendum.

In recent years the Federal Court has built a very sound reputation. I pay tribute to the leadership given to the Court by Sir Nigel Bowen and members of his Court. There would probably not be one judge of the Federal Court who could not earn twice his current salary if he were back at the Bar. I think we should all recognise what a tremendous contribution they make to our democracy. The same can be said about our supreme courts in the States. Again, perhaps we do not often enough put on public record our appreciation of the work which our judges do for our community.

te The Law Reform Commission properly states that one of the arguments against depriving State and Territory courts of admiralty jurisdiction is that removing jurisdiction from those courts could be seen as a downgrading of them. That is a point of view which I share. State supreme courts are obviously an integral part of the judicial system in Australia. They are held in very high regard by the people and are the courts with which most people would associate their thoughts about our judicial system and how it works. I was surprised when the State governments so readily gave up the tax jurisdiction, because that is an important area of work that had been done by the State supreme courts for over a decade. It is important that the State courts retain as wide a spectrum of work as possible and practicable so that they can maintain their expertise and the high respect in which they are held by the community at large. I therefore strongly support the measures in this Bill to confer jurisdiction concurrently.

The Commission has also concerned itself with the actual conduct of trials. In an interesting divergence from standard procedure it has recommended that, through what is now clause 38 in the Bill before us, admiralty actions in rem will be heard by a judge alone without a jury. The coalition is committed to the concept of jury trials and we would normally have some reservations about supporting such a clause. We do, however, appreciate that this is the present de facto situation-that is, there are no jury trials in admiralty jurisdiction in Australia. Given both the complexities of trials and the paucity of actions there is justification for this clause, which abandons trial by jury in admiralty jurisdiction. However, when and if we get around to the constitutional debate and referendums about trial by jury I hope that the Government will refrain from simplistic statements about trial by jury and its significance, bearing in mind that it has presented a Bill to this Parliament which does away with trial by jury in this jurisdiction.

To ensure that no jurisdictional problems arise, the Colonial Courts of Admiralty Act, parts of the Merchant Shipping Act and imperial Acts dating back to the Middle Ages will be repealed by the Bill. There will also be the simultaneous validation of and amendments to the Navigation Act and the Shipping Registration Act. This action, hand in hand with effective rule-making provisions, should clear the fog that encompassed much of this area of law in the past. All in all the Opposition supports the Law Reform Commission's proposals. We believe that they have received wide support from those who are well-acquainted with the situation of admiralty law in Australia. We commend the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for picking up the initiative which was commenced by Senator Durack when he was Attorney-General. We commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed a delight to be able to speak on the Admiralty Bill for two reasons: firstly, because the legislation deals with an enormously complex and sometimes previously archaic area of the law and almost makes it intelligible to the layreader and does make it intelligible to a schooled reader in a way that perhaps was not thought possible in this area of the law a mere few years ago. Secondly, it is a delight to respond to this debate following the remarks of the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) who has been generous in his warmth towards the measures that have been put before the House. He has given full credit to those who have been responsible for bringing the legislation forward. He has mentioned two names with particular commendation, and I also commend them; firstly, Mr Justice Zelling of South Australia whose initial report in 1982 broke ground in terms of setting up a momentum for the reform of this area of the law and, secondly, the Australian Law Reform Commission's report which was subsequently issued, I think in 1986, and which has formed the basis of the present legislation coming before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before the House has considerable virtues: it is expressed briefly and cogently and the language of the enactment, in so far as is possible to deal with these difficult measures, is written in plain and simple English. As well as the commendations that have already been made, I would like to commend the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), those responsible for the drafting of the legislation, the parliamentary draftsmen and the Law Reform Commission for the clarity of their English and the convenience of expression in the legislation.

This is a technical area of the law and one which has not really excited a great deal of lay interest in the past. Nonetheless, it is of considerable importance to those involved in the maritime industry. Australia is, of course, a maritime nation. It places in one Australian Act under the Federal Court system jurisdiction to deal with the disputes that inevitably arise in the course of shipping and associated activities. In the past this area has not been one free from complexity. Indeed, one might think that it was a minefield of constitutional and civil difficulties.

I well recall when I first began practice as a young lawyer and Crown counsel with the Tasmanian Government having to look at a case that was then before the South Australian courts, the China Ocean Shipping case, which involved a collision with a South Australian wharf, I think by a Japanese vessel. The question arose whether the Merchant Shipping Act of 1896 applied in which case the damages that might be awarded in the case were limited to the sum of #14 a ton. The matter was then in issue because that particular provision of the Merchant Shipping Act remained in force. The imperial legislation was still in force in Australia and is only now being effectively removed from the statute books. Similarly the provisions of the Colonial Courts of Admiralty Act, other imperial Acts, and the various State rules that are in the State Supreme Court Acts and rules made under them have all led to a more complicated, vexed and overlapping jurisdictional area. It is to be welcomed not merely by this Parliament, but also by all those who have commercial interests which affect maritime property, that we now have such a well expressed and clear Act which governs the merchant shipping area.

As well as the provisions which simply express existing law, but which do so in an elegant and clear way, there are also new innovations; for example, the section 19 procedure whereby the Act includes provision for the arrest of surrogate vessels. This enables somebody who has been aggrieved-let us take the example of a supplier of goods to a vessel which has sailed from port-to enforce his claims against another vessel of the same line when it arrives in port. It simply makes it a more efficient operation of the system. It indicates that those who have been responsible for the drafting of these provisions have not only looked backwards and tidied up the legislation, but also have looked forward to instances where the legislation can be reformed and made more efficient for those who rely on an efficient system of laws governing the shipping trade. It is a sadness for some of us who grew up trying to fathom the meaning of expressions such as `royal fish', `bottomry' the `sale of ships and shares' and the like that we will no longer have to deal with quite some of the archaic rhetoric of the law. A lot of that will pass with the adoption of this Act, but that is all for the good. It is one area of the law which had fallen well behind the demands of the twentieth century and which is now being brought squarely back into the forefront of our commercial life. I certainly do not wish to proceed clause by clause through this Bill. That has been done by the Attorney-General in his second reading speech. I do not think the substance of those remarks has been brought in issue at all by the Opposition and I understand it is not to be.

Both sides of this House are united in welcoming this legislation. I think the correct English word is that it is `autochthonous' legislation; that is, it springs from indigenous responses to our commercial needs and not reflexively copying something that has happened overseas. In that regard, I welcome it. I also welcome the very generous comments that were made by the honourable member for Flinders about the role and standing of the Federal Court of Australia. When the court was first proposed and brought forward I think there were many who thought that the judges of that division would be thought of as second rate. That is certainly not the case. Those judges have brought with them a stamp of judicial authority and have made their mark so that the Federal Court is now seen as a court which has made a significant contribution to the development of Australia's own indigenous legal system. With that has come the grudging acceptance right across the political spectrum that our High Court of Australia must be the ultimate court of appeal within the Australian legal system and again that is recognised by the present legislation. With those remarks, I welcome this legislation and commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Admiralty Bill is to provide for the admiralty jurisdiction of Australian courts in a form which is comprehensive, accessible and consistent with Australian needs and with international standards concerning civil jurisdiction over ships. This Bill clarifies which claims can be brought in admiralty jurisdiction and which courts can exercise admiralty jurisdiction. As has been said earlier in this debate, the Bill is almost a direct reproduction of the draft Bill recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its report on civil admiralty jurisdiction; that is, report No. 33 of 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: At present, admiralty jurisdiction in Australia is governed by an imperial Act, the Colonial Courts of Admiralty Act 1890. That Act incorporates the then existing admiralty jurisdiction of the English High Court into Australian law; that is, the extent of admiralty jurisdiction applied to Australia by this imperial Act is fixed at the admiralty jurisdiction exercisable by the High Court in England in 1890. This is an archaic arrangement by today's standards. Admiralty jurisdiction in Australia is virtually static but does not include extensions to it that have been incorporated since 1890 in the United Kingdom. Although later legislation, both Australian and imperial, has affected this area of law, Australia's admiralty jurisdiction remains substantially the same as it was at Federation. The Australian Constitution gives the Federal Parliament power to make laws with respect to admiralty and maritime jurisdiction. Other provisions of the Constitution also cover aspects of admiralty jurisdiction, for example, the trade and commerce power and the external affairs power.

The Federal Government's power to enact the Bill comes principally from section 76 (iii) of the Constitution which allows the Parliament to confer jurisdiction on the High Court of Australia in all matters `of admiralty and maritime jurisdiction', and from section 51 (xxxix) which empowers it to regulate incidental and ancillary matters. Some provisions also rely on section 76 (ii) which deals with jurisdiction arising under other laws made by the Parliament. Of particular relevance for the Bill are the Navigation Act 1912, a Commonwealth Act, and the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981, another Commonwealth Act. Section 77 of the Constitution authorises the conferral on State courts of jurisdiction in relation to matters that can be conferred on the High Court. Section 76 which relates to additional original jurisdiction reads:
The Parliament may make laws conferring original jurisdiction on the High Court in any matter-
(i.) Arising under this Constitution, or involving its interpretation:
(ii.) Arising under any laws made by the Parliament:
(iii.) Of admiralty and maritime jurisdiction:
(iv.) Relating to the same subject matter claimed under the laws of different States.
Section 77 which relates to the power to define jurisdiction reads:
With respect to any of the matters mentioned in the last two sections the Parliament may make laws-
(i.) Defining the jurisdiction of any federal court other than the High Court:
(ii.) Defining the extent to which the jurisdiction of any federal court shall be exclusive of that which belongs to or is invested in the courts of the States:
(iii.) Investing any court of a State with federal jurisidction.
The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said in his second reading speech:
Admiralty has long been a distinct jurisdiction in the court system. Business expectations rely on the fact that jurisdiction over ships and ship owners will be assured in special ways.

Indeed, Australia is a country of shippers rather than ship owners and accordingly Australia should have a broad admiralty jurisdiction dependent upon the presence in the jurisdiction of the ship, or a sister ship, in relation to which a maritime claim arises. As the explanatory memorandum to the Bill observes, the Bill regulates admiralty jurisdiction of Australian courts both in actions in rem and in personam. The important distinguishing feature of admiralty jurisdiction is the ability to bring an action in rem. This means that a ship that is in the jurisdiction may be arrested and used as security for a maritime claim. In an action in rem, proceedings are actually instituted against the ship, rather than against its owner or charterer. The Attorney-General stated in his second reading speech:

Actions in rem arise from the existence of a maritime lien or a statutory right of action based on a proprietary or general maritime claim arising under the general law and involving the ownership or operation of ships.

Claims that can be brought in rem include proceedings involving maritime liens which are dealt with in clause 15 of the Bill, and proprietary maritime claims as defined in clause 4 (2) of the Bill. General maritime claims are defined in clause 4 (3) of the Bill which outlines an extensive list covering claims arising out of an operation of a ship. It is necessary, however, in relation to general maritime claims brought in rem that there be a relevant connection between the ship or property and a relevant person-being the person who would be liable in proceedings brought in personam-and in this regard I refer to clauses 17, 18 and 19 of the Bill.

Claims in personam are, as the Attorney-General has stated, directed against a specific person in relation to maritime claims for damage to a ship. Claims that can be brought in personam are maritime claims, both proprietary and general maritime claims; and claims for damage done to a ship as provided in clause 9 (1) of the Bill. As I have said, the Bill preserves the ability to institute an action in rem. It does not purport to embody a total overhaul of the law; it simply aims to clarify the claims that are subject to admiralty jurisdiction, and the rights and liabilities of the parties.

However, the report of the Australian Law Reform Commission raised some problem areas of the jurisdiction in relation to which the Commission declined to provide answers and which are, therefore, not solved in the Bill. For example, where an act or event occurs outside Australian waters and would give rise to a maritime lien under the law of the relevant foreign country but would not under Australian law, should Australia acquire jurisdiction over the matter? The Privy Council answered the question in the negative in relation to Singapore-I refer to the Halcyon Isle case in 1981 Appeal Cases at page 221-but other countries such as Canada have taken the opposite view. The report of the Australian Law Reform Commission observed that this matter was best left to attempts at international unification through the conventions affecting admiralty and maritime jurisdiction. The Law Reform Commission decided generally not to recommend the extension of the accepted scope of the right of action in rem.

It is often difficult to establish the ownership of a foreign vessel. The person dealing with the ship in Australia is likely to be the agent, or a charterer or subcharterer for an associated company or the like. There is an overlap between the remedy of arrest in admiralty jurisdiction and the common law remedy of the Mareva injunction which is an order of a court to a party or other persons over whom the court has jurisdiction, directing the way in which property is to be retained or dealt with so as to ensure that the property will be available to satisfy any judgment in the action. A Mareva injunction was first granted in 1975 by the Court of Appeal in England in the case of Mareva Compania Narierva SA v. International Bulkcarriers SA, reported in 1975, Volume 2 Lloyd's report at page 509.

The report of the Australian Law Reform Commission also said that Mareva injunctions are increasingly being used in relation to ships and cargo both overseas and to a more limited extent in Australia. The report concluded that because the remedy is an evolving one, yet to be fully developed by law, no specific legislative provision should be made about the overlap between the availability of such injunctions and the ability to arrest in rem. The Australian Law Reform Commission considered the establishment of a separate admiralty court but decided against recommending this course of action principally because the volume of work in Australia is too small. Instead, it recommended the granting of in personam jurisdiction to all courts in Australia within the ordinary limits of their civil jurisdiction, such as size of claim, but that in personam jurisdiction should not be given to special purpose courts-for example, the New South Wales Land and Environment Court.

The report further recommended that jurisdiction over actions in rem should be allocated only to superior courts because of the severity of the consequences of arresting a ship, but superior courts should be given the power to remit in rem actions to inferior courts in appropriate cases, for example, because of the small size of the claim. A court will have jurisdiction in accordance with the limits of that court as to amount claimed and remedies but not otherwise. Hence, claims for smaller amounts will be able to be brought in lower courts such as district or county courts.

Clause 9 (2) of the Bill provides that the only exception is limitation proceedings which can be brought only in supreme courts or the Federal Court. Clause 10 of the Bill confers jurisdiction on the Federal Court and supreme courts of Territories and States in respect of proceedings commenced as actions in rem under this Act. There is provision in clause 11 for other courts to have in rem jurisdiction conferred on them. It should be noted that no original jurisdiction in admiralty matters will be conferred on the High Court of Australia.

To sum up, the important provisions of the Bill are that it is to apply to all ships and all claims wherever arising. Clause 4 of the Bill defines maritime claims. `Proprietary maritime claims' are defined to include, for example, claims relating to possession, ownership or mortgage of a ship. `General maritime claims' are defined to include, for example, claims for damage done by a ship, claims for loss of life or personal injury as a result of a defect in a ship or in the apparel or equipment and claims arising out of an act or omission of a ship's owner or the person in possession of the ship. As I have mentioned, jurisdiction is conferred on the various courts by part II of the Bill. Above all, provision is made for transferring matters begun in one court to another court with the appropriate jurisdiction. This is a special innovation contained in this Bill.

The imperial legislation that has governed admiralty jurisdiction in Australia is to be repealed, as I have already said, by part IV of the Bill. The Governor-General is empowered to make rules, under clause 41, for governing the practice and procedure of the courts exercising admiralty jurisdiction and regulations generally. The Bill has received bipartisan support in this chamber. It is an historic piece of legislation and I am sure it will be adopted by the Senate as soon as it is debated in that House. It will enable practitioners of admiralty law and the courts which will now be empowered to deal with admiralty actions in this country a vehicle with which to bring sense and certainty to admiralty law. Above all, the clients who have to deal with admiralty law will have an established set of practices and procedures upon which they can go to the courts for quick and sure guidance. That has been lacking for nearly 90 years.

I commend the Bill to the House. I join with other members in congratulating the Australian Law Reform Commission and those who participated in the preparation and drafting of the report which was considered by the Attorney-General prior to his preparation of this Bill now under consideration by the House. They deserve the congratulations of all the legal fraternity in this country on the excellent work they have done. Their work will stand as a milestone of competence by the Australian Law Reform Commission and will bring to the legal profession, including judges, who will be involved in administering Australia's admiralty law, a piece of legislation which is easily understandable and able to be easily adjudicated. This legislation will enhance maritime trade for those who have to abide by the law and regulations under this Bill.
