TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The amendments proposed in the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1988 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1988 will enable the Federal Government to implement its part of a second package of reforms for the Australian road transport industry. This Government is the only government in Australia's history to have attended to the problems of our national road freight industry. Since it initiated the National Road Freight Inquiry in 1983, chaired by Mr Tom May, the Labor Government has worked closely with State and Territory governments and the road transport industry to provide sensible and productive reforms. We have introduced significant efficiencies to the industry, improved its safety and recognised the difficulties faced by many truckies. We will continue to develop these reforms which will have major flow-on to the needs of Australian industry as a whole, to our economy, and our international trade.

Transport is a major sector in the Australian economy. It accounts for about 17 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product, with the road transport sector contributing about $16 billion per year to value-added output or 7.5 per cent of gross domestic product. Transport costs make up over 40 per cent of the final product price for the mining industry; between 6 and 12 per cent for primary products; and 13 per cent for manufacturing. Road transport costs typically account for around 5 per cent of product costs in the more trade-exposed parts of the manufacturing sector. Road transport will continue to play a predominant role in the Australian economy. By the year 2000 total road use is expected to be about 60 per cent above the 1985 level.

People often forget the geographic size of our country. They forget the distances over which our raw materials have to be carried, and too often make specious comparisons attempting to focus on transport costs as a scapegoat for their competitive position. We know that there are efficiencies to be gained and over the last five years we have achieved much with shipping costs, with our railways-particularly Australian National-and with road freight. Our road freight industry is, in fact, one of our most competitive industries and internationally we are renowned for our trucking expertise.

The May report has provided a blueprint for the development of the industry. The first set of reforms based on the report was the fast-track package of reforms, which commenced on 1 January 1987. Central to the fast-track package was the Federal interstate registration scheme, which was established under the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Act 1985. This scheme provides for the registration of vehicles engaged solely in interstate trade and commerce and the payment of reasonable registration charges which recover the cost of road wear.

On the initiative of this Government, State and Territory Ministers endorsed the second stage package at the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC) ministerial meeting last December. I commend the former Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support for his contribution. The reforms are being introduced cooperatively by Federal, State and Territory governments and have the strong support of industry. The package comprises: increasing the national speed limit for heavy vehicles in non-urban areas to 100 kilometres per hour; revising driving hours in the eastern mainland States to reflect more realistically modern Australian conditions; and introducing revised registration charges and new registration categories providing for higher and nationally uniform load limits under the Federal interstate registration scheme. The increase in the heavy vehicle speed limit to 100 kilometres per hour outside built up areas will improve safety by removing the disparity between truck and car speeds. This will reduce the need for overtaking, which has been identified as a major road safety problem. The move to this limit follows an interim increase to 90 kilometres per hour, which was evaluated over 12 months. The results of this evaluation showed that there had been no adverse road safety implications from the increase to 90 kilometres per hour.

The introduction of uniform revised driving hours arrangements along the eastern mainland seaboard acknowledges the realities of modern vehicle design, today's road conditions and existing practices. Overall weekly driving hours will increase only slightly, but more flexibility is provided to meet the varying needs of different operators. Driving hours will be enforced by an enhanced log book system, with the alternative option of approved tachographs. The impact of the new speed limit and revised driving hours will be closely monitored and enforced. ATAC Ministers called on the road transport industry to demonstrate a responsible attitude to the introduction of the new package. Industry associations support the concept of realistic enforcement. The industry supports the reform package.

The changes to the Federal legislation will provide for new vehicle categories to be introduced under the Federal registration scheme to allow federally registered vehicles to operate at higher mass limits. This arrangement will obviate the need for the existing vehicle mass permit schemes in New South Wales and Victoria for federally registered vehicles. For the first time federally registered vehicles will be able to operate at a uniform limit across Australia.

This morning I announced the registration charges to apply from 1 July 1988 for vehicles registered under the Federal interstate registration scheme. The revised charges are a further step in pursuing our commitment to allowing truck owners to make a fair contribution to maintaining our road infrastructure. They include the new classes of vehicles operating at higher mass limits. In determining the charges, consideration has been given to the Inter-State Commission's 1987 review of Federal registration charges for interstate vehicles. Money collected from registration charges will continue to be returned to State and Territory governments for the maintenance and upkeep of roads used by federally registered vehicles.

Let me now turn to the individual amendments. The principal amendment in the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill provides for new registration categories to be established to enable vehicles to operate at mass limits up to 42.5 tonnes under the Federal interstate registration scheme. To implement the higher mass limits a specific regulatory power has been used. In addition, a general regulatory power for vehicle operating standards has also been inserted into the Act allowing us to implement a smoking ban on Federal interstate buses and coaches. This will also enable us to act quickly to achieve further reforms for the industry in the future. The smoking ban was agreed to by Federal and State Ministers and will complement similar State legislation to be introduced during 1988.

Clause 12 provides the general regulation-making power covering vehicle operating standards which will be used to implement this ban. These provisions are in line with the ban on smoking on commercial passenger aircraft which commenced on 1 December 1987. Let me emphasise that at this stage the regulation-making powers will apply only to new regulations for the control of mass limits and to implement the ban on smoking in interstate buses and coaches. The continued willingness of States to implement jointly agreed reforms will mean that the general use of these regulatory powers should be minimal.

Clause 6 clears the way to introduce increased mass limits for federally registered vehicles and clause 5 expressly exempts Federal vehicles from the need to obtain a State permit for operating at the higher mass limits. Consequential amendments are required to the Interstate Road Transport Charge Act. They will enable the Government to set registration charges to offset the extra costs of road wear for 42.5 tonne vehicles. The charge for vehicles over 38 tonnes is $3,135. The legislation will set a charge limit of $5,000 for these vehicles. Any increase above this limit would require an amendment to the legislation. The $1,000 limit for other classes of vehicles will be retained. The remaining minor amendments are of an administrative nature and are required to streamline operations for the benefit of both the State authorities which administer the registration scheme and the users-the road transport industry.

The Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill provides for the amendments to come into force on 1 July 1988. State Ministers of the Australian Transport Advisory Council have accepted this introduction date. I must say that Tasmania will require some further time. A number of factors are to be considered. The net budgetary impact of these amendments will be nil. All registration charges will be paid into the Interstate Road Transport Trust Fund and will continue to be fully distributed to the States and Territories. All administrative costs incurred by State and Territory authorities administering the scheme are met through the levying of fees. No additional staffing requirements or administration will arise for the Federal Department of Transport and Communications. The charges for vehicles in the new categories will be offset by increased efficiency and productivity for the road transport industry. Bus and coach industry organisations claim that the ban on smoking will reduce maintenance costs.

The reforms being realised in the interstate road transport amendment Bills reflect the importance of road transport for the Australian economy. They are another constructive step towards achieving the Government's goal of restructuring the economy; part of the Government's micro-economic reform package for achieving an efficient transport industry. I commend the Bill and present the explanatory memoranda for this Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1988 to honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Amendment Bill covers a wide range of areas in the Social Security Act and makes a number of amendments which the Opposition is prepared to support, although some will require further explanation in due course. In the second reading speech the point is made that the objective of the Government is to improve the quality of administration and decision making in the social security portfolio. Furthermore it is suggested that the Government intends first to ensure that every Australian resident obtains adequate income support as and when it is needed and secondly to protect the revenue by ensuring that the payments are not directed to those who do not require them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill makes the very significant and important change of requiring that in future, where compensation settlements are made, those people who have up to the date of settlement been claiming either unemployment or sickness benefits, for example, will be required to pay back the sum total of those benefits, and for the purposes of the Act 50 per cent of lump sum settlements will be taken as being the result of economic loss. Experts in this area may have some concern about the impact of that in the event that it could, for example, discriminate against people who receive personal compensation settlements which, in fact, required that more than 50 per cent be the result of economic loss. Nevertheless, we will be watching the situation to make sure that it does not develop in a way that allows people to be unfairly treated as a result of that particular amendment.

The legislation also covers the loss of income component of West German restitution payments when assessing the rate of pension or benefit. This has been a particular matter of concern to the Opposition and, I might add, to the Jewish community of Australia, particularly in relation to those who were victims of the Holocaust. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in a Press release of 30 November 1987 entitled `Restitution payments for Nazi victims', emphasised the fact that the Act `would be amended to clarify the way social security income tests are applied to restitution paid by the German Government to people who were persecuted by the Hitler regime'. This was a decision taken by the Government, flowing from discussions with the Australian Jewish Welfare Societies and the Minister. Regrettably, however, in our discussions with the Jewish community and the Welfare Societies it has become quite clear that they are not satisfied with the interpretation of `income' in the proposed legislative changes.

It is worth noting that West German restitution payments are provided by the West German Government for approximately 1,000 people living in Australia who suffered under the Nazi regime. These people were either in concentration camps or elsewhere, but one way or the other they certainly suffered as a result of the depradations of that monstrous administration of Germany. Following the war they migrated to Australia. The size of the restitution payments depends on the individual's war history and suffering and the general range is between $100 and $300 a month.

While the proposed amendment seeks to make a clear distinction as to what is defined as loss of income and what is not for the purposes of the pension income test, we believe, as do the Jewish welfare organisations, that it has failed to solve the problem effectively. This is for two reasons. First, those who are in receipt of compensation payments are assessed on a percentage basis for loss of health. A component of this may be described nominally as a loss of earning capacity. The Government's proposed amendment could be interpreted in such a way as to have the entire restitution payment described as income. In the event that it is described as income or considered as such by the Department, of course that would become subject to the income test under the Act. Secondly, there is a group of people who come under the Reichversicherung rules in that they would have been working in Germany between 1933 and 1939. In that capacity, as with all Germans at that stage and ever contemporaneously, they automatically paid superannuation from their salaries. Effectively, it was a compulsory superannuation payment.

As a result of the nazi restitution laws of 1949, some of these people are eligible for entitlements because of the income losses they clearly suffered. Despite the Government's proposed amendment these payments could still be interpreted as income and, as I said, therefore become subject to the provisions of the Act which would effectively limit the pensions that these people may receive. So, while referring to loss of income-and rightly so-the Bill fails to define what is income. In consequence of this, at the committee stage of the Bill I shall be moving an amendment to clause 3 to overcome this outstanding difficulty in the Act at present.

The Act also covers a range of other matters, such as minor changes to the family allowance supplement (FAS). It allows, for example, the apportionment of advance leave payments as income over the period of leave. It treats lump sum payments for termination of employment as having been received on the last day of employment. It apportions arrears of education allowance over the period covered by the payment and it backdates payments of FAS to the date that education payment started to accrue, provided the FAS is claimed or received within six weeks of the date of first receipt of education allowance payment. It also makes some changes in relation to the job search allowance. This is of particular relevance to the children of pensioners, because it excludes them from the operation of parental income test, which applies to persons who are in receipt of an income.

In addition to that, it bases the parental income test on income during the last completed financial year, not part of a financial year. We believe that is a worthwhile and sensible change. In relation to the payment of supporting parents' benefits and widows pensions, it is also a very important but easily missed administrative problem with the earlier Act of last year that under the new arrangements parents whose dependent children are between the ages of 16 and 24 attract child disability allowance and who, because they are either physically or mentally handicapped, will in fact be protected. The House will recall that the Government did change this arrangement after the last election, to the extent that the supporting parents' benefits would only be payable to children under the age of 16 and in that case on the basis of an income test on their parents. Children over that age would not receive the benefit, the alleged reason being that in most cases they would qualify for the Austudy arrangements.

The Government has tended to ignore the problem of horizontal equity in a situation like this which does not, to all intents and purposes, take account of the difficulties of people who may notionally be in what we could describe as middle income brackets but at the same time have a large number of children. I have previously made the point in the House that by no stretch of the imagination can we compare the financial position of people on an income basis, irrespective of the levels of income being compared. A single man on $50,000 or even a married couple on $50,000 with no children cannot be compared with parents with five children in a similar income situation. Regrettably, this Act, as with other changes to the tax arrangements over recent years made by this Government, has effectively ignored that very important factor.

The same principle applies to some degree in relation to the application of the Austudy arrangements. The essential ingredient of the Minister's second reading speech in the House was his allegation-if I may use that term-that the Government is in the business of embarking on a major program to improve the actual distribution of social security benefits and so forth to those who are in need and, above all, to create a more equitable society. On this side of the House I would support the objective of creating a more equitable society, which I hasten to add does not mean a more egalitarian society.

Just as we were not born equal, none of us are going to die equal. We have different skills and abilities. The question that a government has to address is how our policies can be best determined to ensure that those skills and abilities and the opportunities which individual citizens have available to them are as fair and equitable as possible. What individuals make of those opportunities, regrettably, is not an element on which government policy by itself is able to make much direct impact. In consequence of this, however, and because of the major concern the Opposition has at the fact that the Australian people have demonstrated in elections across this land over the last six months a growing perception that the Government is out of touch with the real problems facing the average Australian-whether he be a family man or not, but I emphasise that family people are the ones with the biggest problems-we will be moving an amendment to the second reading motion of this Bill, which I quote for the benefit of the House:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House deplores the facts that (a) the Hawke Government's economic and social polices continue to cause a fall in living standards for Australian families, and (b) the Prime Minister has refused to meet his 1987 election pledge that by 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty''.

The average Australian family today needs a further $42 a week to restore its disposable income to the point where it was in March 1983. Over five years of Government policy, with all the alleged changes which it has introduced, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Ministers have continually said, `There is nothing wrong with our policies. The only thing wrong with them is that they have not been sold properly'. That is an extraordinary statement coming from the person who, we have been told for the last five years at least, is Australia's greatest communicator.

I think it demonstrates beyond any reasonable doubt that there are a number of fundamental problems to which the Government has not been prepared to direct its efforts. While on the one hand, for example, it talks about reducing the incidence of tax on Australians, and particularly on Australian families, the simple fact of the matter is that through inflation, through the bracket creep, despite the reductions in tax which have taken place, the impact of those changes has been of much more benefit to those on higher incomes than it has been to those on lower incomes.

Is it any wonder, therefore, that in the New South Wales State elections in electorates such as the electorate of Minchinbury, with Green Valley and Mount Druitt in the western suburbs of Sydney-which most people would say have more than their fair share of social and economic problems-people voted predominantly Liberal, because they simply have lost confidence in the capacity and the willingness of this Labor Government, a so-called government of compassion and concern, to take any real notice of their problems.

A few months ago, in one of my visits to that part of Sydney I was taken to see a caravan park. I must have seen at least 50 to 60 caravans. The occupants were not people who were just coming to the western suburbs of Sydney for a holiday. One does not generally go to places like Mount Druitt and Green Valley for a holiday. If one does, one does not stay in a caravan. These were Australian families, for the most part. The children were not getting a decent education. There was not a tree to be seen. At the back of the caravans they were building the next generation of accommodation. It reminded me of what I saw in Soweto rather than what I should see in Sydney-little square blocks. They were not giving people caravans any more; they were going to give them square block sheds. All the washing and laundry facilities were common. There were common ablution blocks the like of which I had to suffer when I was in the army cadets many years ago. In the winter time those families freeze. In the summer time they bake in an open area which, as I said, is covered by dirt and dust-treeless. The horrifying part is that those families were paying $125 a week.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—$125 a week, to live in a two-wheeled caravan-the sort of thing you would bundle your kids in for 36 hours, and after that your wife complains and wants to go home. But those families were living there, and I regret to say that what I saw is being mirrored probably right across Australia today. It is demonstrated by the fact that we now have a waiting list of some 160,000 units for public housing in this country. Yet we are told that this Government has faced up to and understands the problems. `We are listening', says the Prime Minister when he makes those rare visits to the real world. He says, `We are listening', but I wonder what he has to say to those people out there in Minchinbury. What does he have to say to the people living in those conditions across the nation?

SPEECH.PARA: I remember in the late 1960s I was in the United States where I was brought face to face, for the first time in my life I might add, with what is called temporary accommodation or mobile homes. I was shocked and I said to one of the Americans with me, `We would never let that happen in Australia. We would never allow our housing situation to reach the stage where people have to live in homes on wheels because we cannot give them even the vestige of a basic house with two or three bedrooms'. What I saw there brought home to me, as I hope it would bring home to all members of the Government, that when we talk about poverty in Australia today we must recognise that poverty is real, it is grinding and cutting at the vitals of our nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do about it?

—What are we going to do about it? The truth of the matter is that after five years it is time to ask the Government, `What are you going to do about it? Why has it taken you the best part of five years even to acknowledge that there is a problem?'. The problem has a number of elements. The Government has deliberately presided over a lowering of the standard of living for the vast majority of Australians, and it takes some pride in saying that. The trouble is that the lowering of standards has affected those at the bottom much more than those at the top. The sad fact is that any analysis that one cares to read on wealth distribution in society leads one to suggest that those at the top have done extremely well over the past five years. Clearly, those towards the bottom know that they have not done well and that they cannot make ends meet.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's only answer to all that has been the family assistance supplement, which we support. It is a logical extension of the old family income supplement arrangement, and it is desperately needed. But again the evidence is quite clear: by 1990, to use the chosen date of the Prime Minister, the Government will be nowhere near removing poverty from Australia. That was a stupid comment, one which the Opposition will not allow the Prime Minister to forget and one which those who are living in and experience poverty will also not forget. The Melbourne Herald in its editorial of Monday, 11 April this year, put it aptly when it stated:

When a politician makes a statement that so stretches credulity, as the Prime Minister did last year, it can and often is dismissed as mere political rhetoric. In this case, despite big headlines at the time, that is exactly what happened. And on the way the poor children, who do not have a powerful voice in the political jungle, stay poor.

Money is not enough, and in many respects that is where the Prime Minister made his fundamental error; he presumed that we would be credulous enough to believe that, provided absolute incomes for poor families increased marginally-and we are talking about money only at the margin, regrettably-somehow or other everything else would fall into place.

The fact is that, while poverty is closely related to the lack of money, which is essential just to stay alive and clothe oneself, it is much wider than that. Essentially, poverty involves the inability of a person to utilise the normal range of opportunities that most of us take for granted in our society. Persons are in poverty when they cannot obtain an adequate education; persons are in poverty when they cannot find employment; persons are in poverty if they are a member of a single parent family that has been ignored and denied the normal elements of family support by the non-custodial parent for so long. Again, the Opposition is delighted that at long last, after five years of shillyshallying, the Government has its act together and is moving in the area of maintenance support, despite the fact that it called the legislation by another name. It is not a family support package; it is no more nor less than a maintenance package. If the legislation was a support package, most people would presume that that would mean that all children in need would be supported. Even presuming that we could get 70 per cent of those involved to pay some maintenance, at least 30 per cent would continue to pay no maintenance for one reason or another. There has been no suggestion by the Government that families under those circumstances will be better off than they are today.

I make that point because we in this Parliament and elsewhere have a tendency to throw around numbers and try to obfuscate the issues by saying things like, `We are helping 30 per cent' and then calling it quits. The fact is that we must ensure that the 30 per cent to whom we give maximum assistance as far as we are financially able are those who need assistance the most-those at the bottom. The point I am making, therefore, is that to many people a few dollars is not enough to prevent them from being in poverty. As the Prime Minister learnt to his cost when he made those statements, merely giving money to the parents of children, regrettably, is no guarantee that those children will be any better off at all. If the answer is that we should take the children from their parents, I am certain that no one in this House would support that approach but, as I said previously, it demonstrates the point that any respectable definition of poverty includes much more than simply the provision of greater sums of money. The problem involves encouraging and helping those families to do better by their children while at the same time ensuring that our educational and housing systems, and so on, are adequate and give as much support as this nation can provide, given the very large range of alternatives that the taxation dollar is expected to provide according to the other responsibilities of government.

As I have said, we have conceded that the child support package has gone some way towards alleviating these difficulties. The President of the Australian Council of Social Service, Mr Julian Disney, said that, even after the full impact of the Government's new family allowance supplement, about 400,000 children would still remain impoverished. Academics Brownlee and King in their paper `The Working Poor' claim that the main group of families has been lifted above the poverty line but that much more needs to be done for families on pensions and benefits. As I said previously, housing is a fundamental problem. Housing costs should be placed high on the policy agenda in continuing the fight against poverty. An analysis of the poor demonstrates one interesting fact: those in greatest poverty are those who are paying private rent. In places like Sydney in particular, people are facing extremely difficult situations and the poor have effectively been driven out of the inner suburbs towards the fringe of the city. That creates another set of problems involving communications, transport and so on, making it even more difficult for many of those people to find employment.

Examinations have also been made on the impact of the Government's family package in reducing both the number of children living in poverty and the size of the gap between family incomes and the poverty line. After considering the costs of providing housing, Brownlee and King found that 148,000 children in working families and 260,800 children in pensioner beneficiary families would still be living below the poverty line. In their study they stressed the need not just for money incomes but that the Government must consider `other forms of material well-being' such as assets or fringe benefits. They also noted that consideration of income transfers alone did not attack the root causes of poverty and stated that parallel policies are required in areas such as employment, education and housing. In other words, it will take much more than increased income to eliminate child poverty.

I would like to make a few observations about the impact of the taxation system in this whole area. While people tend to say that the very poor do not pay any taxes because they are below the threshold and that therefore the taxation system cannot affect them, the difficulty contemporary Australian society faces is that the threshold of poverty is in fact going up-in other words, more people are finding themselves on the margin or below that line. That increase in poverty automatically suggests that the current tax thresholds are not adequate to keep up with the problem.

One of the major related problems-and this matter is not unique to the present Government-is that when reference is made to cash transfer payments from the Budget, such payments are very obvious. Everyone knows about them, they are clearly seen and people get upset about the fact that 28 per cent of the Budget goes in social security payments, et cetera. People are not aware of the fact that support can also be made available through the taxation system. Then, the figures are effectively hidden. The time has come when a very thorough analysis needs to be done about what sections of the community do best out of the tax transfer arrangements on the one hand, and out of direct support through the taxation system on the other. I believe such an analysis will reveal some glaring inconsistencies.

As I have said, the Opposition parties support the essential ingredients of this legislation. From time to time the need arises to introduce into the House arrangements that will improve social security legislation and overcome anomalies when they appear. Regrettably, changes such as those contained in the legislation demonstrate that quite a few problems have arisen. However, essentially the objective of social security policy must be to create a more equitable distribution of wealth in our society. Different mechanisms can be used to achieve that goal.

As the Institute of Family Studies has pointed out, not enough consideration has been given over the last few years-certainly not over the last five years-to the fundamental problem that, under the existing taxation system, the people who decide to bring up children in our society and who thus play a vital role in assuring the continuity of our population have not been given a fair go. The only support they have effectively received from this Government-and, as I have said, it has been very belated-has been through the family allowance supplement in the fifth and sixth years of the Government's administration. To that point, nothing was done. On the contrary, the Government changed the taxation system in such a way that it gave up any pretence of support through horizontal equity.

That is the point with which I started my speech and it is one of the points with which I want to finish it. The taxation system needs to be reviewed to give special emphasis to the problems facing Australian families who are bringing up children, often in very real distress. There is not the slightest doubt that people who have children in their family suffer a fall in real income, but that obvious fact has so far been completely ignored by the Government, and a change of policy in this direction must be made as soon as possible, hopefully by May.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many issues in the Social Security Amendment Bill on which we could spend a few hours. Obviously, any one member can cover only a few of these issues. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) has moved a two-part amendment. The major part indicates that the Opposition is prepared to give the Bill a second reading. However, the amendment goes on to try to score debating points. To a certain extent I agree with the honourable member for Bradfield that poverty, obviously, is not only about money. I think honourable members on both sides of the House would realise that. We do not need the honourable member for Bradfield to tell us. We realise that poverty does mean the lack of educational opportunities and the lack of other opportunities to persons in the poverty cycle. The important point is that this Bill is an attempt to deal with the Social Security Act, which, in some ways has, developed over the years into a bit of a hotchpotch. Over time we begin to realise that there are issues which do need to be attended to and which do have a priority which they did not have before and that as a result of those priorities we have to change the Act. This Bill does precisely that.

SPEECH.PARA: In supporting the Bill I remind honourable members on both sides of the House of the tremendous advances in social welfare legislation which have been the result of initiatives of this Government. This Bill is in line with those advances. Certainly, we cannot be complacent about a situation in which there are still too many children living in poverty, half of whom are in sole parent families, yet the Government is attempting to tackle that problem. Our child support legislation, for example, was the first step taken by any government in Australia to tackle the problem of poverty caused by one partner of a marriage leaving the matrimonial home and evading his or her responsibilities by not paying maintenance to help support the children.

The failure of many non-custodial parents to live up to their responsibilities means that most sole parents have had to rely heavily on social security support. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) stated in the second reading speech when she presented the Bill on behalf of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe):
. . . this Labor Government has embarked on a program of major improvements in the quality of administration and decision making in the social security portfolio.

(Quorum formed) Once again the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) has abused the privileges of the House in calling a quorum. Members of the Government have been in committees, working hard and putting all their efforts into trying to run this country. Apart from the honourable members on this side of the House we have just three members of the Opposition in the chamber to listen to this very important debate. So much for their interest in the Bill that is before the House.

Before I was interrupted I was talking about the second reading speech in which the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel was placing emphasis on the fact that this program has dual objectives: Firstly, to ensure that every Australian resident obtains adequate income support as and when it is needed; and, secondly, to protect the revenue by ensuring that payments are not directed to those who do not require them. Both these objectives emphasise aspects of equity and social justice which are the very roots of the Labor Party's reason for existence.

Over the past five years this Government has commenced the job of rebuilding industry, reviving employment, expanding the social wage and restoring welfare provisions to improve the lives of the ordinary people of Australia. Yet those of us on this side of the House are conscious of the fact that there is still much more that can and should be done in all these areas. The Opposition, for its part, seems to take the view that all it needs to do is to reduce the expenditure on social security. It would do this by cutting programs-but it does not say what programs it would like to cut-and by denying help to those who most need it. That is its way; it is not our way to achieve equity and social justice. This Government has made it clear that we will continue to improve the standard of living of all those resident in Australia who cannot adequately support themselves. At the same time we will ensure that there is a close scrutiny of social security programs and administration in order to protect the taxpayers of this country from excessive taxation.

I will now attempt to examine the Bill in some detail. On 8 February 1988 the Minister for Social Security announced that as from that day all workers compensation and common law consent awards and settlements would be subject to a new rule to cut out double dipping in the social security system. Measures to stop double dipping in compensation awards for people on sickness benefits were extended on 1 May 1987 to cover people receiving unemployment and special benefits, invalid pension and sheltered employment and rehabilitation allowances. Unfortunately, it has been found that some people have tried to disguise payments to avoid repayments to social security or to avoid being precluded from social security payments for a certain time. The Department of Social Security takes into account only compensation made for economic loss; payments for specific injuries are normally exempted.

Unfortunately, many compensation awards and settlements have not accurately described the true nature of payments and have misled the Department. It was as a result of this abuse that the Minister indicated that, as from 9 May 1988, 50 per cent of any lump sum payment will be deemed to be for economic loss. Social Security payments will be recovered on that basis. This Bill in part formalises the new arrangements and will help to improve the administration and integrity of compensation recovery provisions. It should be noted, however, that where a court has made an order after a contested hearing specifying the economic loss component, the Secretary to the Department will be obliged to continue to have regard to the characterisation given to the award by the court.

The point must be made that the Department has reviewed compensation cases which have come within its purview and has found that most people will be better off under the 50 per cent rule because most people receive more than 50 per cent of their award for economic loss in lump sums. It should also be made clear that the Department is not seeking to recover 50 per cent of the lump sum. In cases where Social Security payments have been made in the past and the lump sum payments are not large, the Department may in fact recover less than the amount of pensions actually paid. Certain costs associated with compensation claims are automatically exempted. These costs include legal and medical costs.

In the time remaining I will turn to some other aspects of this Bill. I am very pleased-and I am sure all disabled persons and their organisations will be pleased-that a sole parent with a child who attracts the child disability allowance will not lose his or her entitlement to sole-parent's pension when that child turns 16 years of age. This is in recognition of the fact that there is a great deal of care required for a disabled child. It is a measure of compensation for the direct and indirect costs associated with providing care and attention for a disabled child. This Bill has the merit of enhancing the access of social security claimants to the social security system in a number of ways. One of these relates to the family allowance supplement (FAS).

Honourable members have spoken at some length on this in this debate; in particular, the treatment of lump sums under the income test. At the moment persons who take leave from their employment and who are paid in a lump sum may forfeit their FAS if the lump sum is treated as income within the period of receipt. Of course, this disadvantages those who receive leave payments in a lump sum compared with those whose leave payments are staggered by their employers. Under this Bill people who take leave from employment and who are paid in a lump sum will have their payment spread over the period of leave. Lump sum education payments will also be spread over the period to which they relate. Student parents who in 1988 were not aware of their family allowance supplement entitlements until they received education payments are now protected under this Bill. As the education payments may be made in respect of an earlier period, FAS will be payable to cover this earlier period of entitlement. I am very pleased to see that improvements will also be made to the parental income test of the job search allowance. The year of parental income that is tested will be moved forward to the year ending in the month of June of the previous financial year rather than the month of June in the previous calendar year. This will assist in ensuring that the level of payment is more closely aligned to real need. There are a number of other important changes to the Social Security Act contained in this Bill but time prevents me from expanding on them. In conclusion, this is an excellent Bill which deserves the support of this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take part in this debate on a piece of legislation which is making a series of minor amendments to express disappointment that the range of those minor amendments is not extensive enough and, furthermore, that in the making of the minor amendments we have an identification of the fact that the Government is failing to face up to the real problems that confront Australia and those who are dependent upon our social security system. I am and have been for many years a supporter of a universal approach to social security and family support arrangements. In so far as the Social Security Amendment Bill makes some minor adjustments to the family allowance supplement I think those adjustments are just tinkering at the edges.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) said that his Government wanted to focus on families and individuals in need. To achieve a fair and equitable tax and social security system we need both vertical equity and horizontal equity. We need to make sure that the total household income of families is sufficient to support and educate their children. At the same time we need to recognise that high income families that are supporting dependent spouses and dependent children are recognised, either through the tax system or through the family allowance system.

The present Government has said that a high income family that is supporting a dependent spouse and dependent children is not in need, even in comparison with a single taxpayer on the same income. So a family with a combined income of $50,000 a year, or just over, under the Hawke Labor Government gets no family allowance. If a family gets no family allowance because its income is too high as a result of the combined efforts of husband and wife, mother and father, both with a job, and one of them loses his job, unless the income that is lost through, say, the secondary earner losing or giving up her job reduces the total family income by 25 per cent, the family does not regain its entitlement to family allowances, even if the household income is substantially below the threshold at which the family allowance in those circumstances cuts out. That is totally unfair. It is unfair not because of the way a stupid means test operates but because of the stupidity of a system that denies to all families supporting dependent children an equality of tax relief or, alternatively, cash allowance payments.

We are about to see this Labor Government create further anomalies. There is a family allowance supplement and some minor amendments to the means test being legislated for in this legislation, but it looks as though the present Government is about to introduce an arrangement whereby non-custodial parents will be required to make a more substantial contribution towards the support of their children than they have made in the past. In doing so we will find that the non-custodial parent will not be supporting his children fully to the same extent as the custodial parent unless his income is in excess of $34,000 to $36,000 a year. In other words, we will have a system that provides child support only to families that are intact and whose income is about $20,000 a year. But, for separated families, that support will continue, even when the family income is at least 50 per cent higher and possibly, on a combined basis, double the level of the intact family's income. That is a crazy system to be implementing. Yet this Government says that it is concerned about families.

What this country lacks, and what the present Government has failed to implement, is a sensible family policy that acknowledges the need, throughout the family life cycle, for tax relief for those families who support their dependent children and those children's dependent mothers. It is sad that when we make these minor amendments there is no acknowledgment of the important need to develop a family policy that treats children not as consumption goods but as the future of the nation. We need a family policy that sets taxation and social security in the context of life cycle accounting. Too often governments just look at annual Budgets, taxing individuals and their families on an annual basis, without regard to the life cycle commitments of those individuals and their families.

In the few minutes at my disposal I draw the attention of the House to another area. Although minor amendments are made in the Bill I am disappointed that it fails again to look at this problem. Many age pensioners today are subject to income tax. The only thing that prevents some of them being liable to income tax is the age tax allowance or rebate. The gap between pension income and the point at which their tax liability accrues is narrow indeed. Many pensioners, as a consequence, have to meet what to them are substantial tax liabilities once a year. I fail to understand why the Director of Social Security is deemed for taxation purposes to be an employer of the pensioners to whom he is paying a pension. He knows their income or should, and should withdraw the relatively small amounts each week of the tax that those pensioners would otherwise have to pay to relieve them of the heavy burden at the end of the financial year of making a substantial tax payment.

Furthermore, the Director of Social Security not only should be required to look at income in retrospect in assessing a person's entitlement to a pension but also he should be required to ask all pensioners to reconcile their income receipts on an annual basis so that the unders and overs can be adjusted by looking back over the experience of the year and adjustments then made, rather than imposing upon pensioners a requirement to notify over a very short period any adjustment of their income that occurs during the year. We need a far more efficient and effective administrative arrangement to determine both the pension entitlement of aged pensioners and others and the tax liability of those pensioners. I am disappointed that that is not contained in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Opposition should apologise for interrupting such an important dinner with our visitors from Europe. I want to refer to the comments made by the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) in this debate on the Social Security Amendment Bill. I need some clarification, because I am sure I heard him just before the dinner break advocating that pensioners should be taxed automatically by the Department of Social Security. We heard him say that the Department of Social Security ought to project additional income and pre-tax pensioners. We ought to place that on the record and let the people hear what the Liberal Party is saying. No wonder it is saying that. It is the same Party that in government reduced pensions by 2.4 per cent. It is the same Liberal Party that, in coalition government with the National Party, sought to destroy all the medical benefits and health systems in this country. These are the same parties that have again threatened to impose all sorts of penalties on the people of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no wonder that honourable members opposite stand up and argue against the amendments in this legislation: the amendments are brought forward by a government that is determined to ensure that every Australian resident obtains adequate income support when it is needed. It is also a government that is determined to protect its revenue base by ensuring that the payments made are directed to those who need them, not to those who do not. This is a government that has a commitment to the needy, not the greedy. It is no wonder that the honourable member for Sturt and other members of the Liberal Party want to criticise this Government. We know their record and we know of the impositions they threaten to place upon the people of Australia. Thank goodness they will never get into government again.

I turn to the second reading speech prepared by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and delivered on his behalf when these amendments were introduced a few weeks ago. He pointed out that we have to ensure that we proceed with this Government's commitment to ensuring that there is efficiency in the welfare system, to removing the gaps and removing the anomalies. That is what this amending legislation we are dealing with tonight does. I also acknowledge that this is the Government that has accepted its responsibility to improve the quality of life for the aged, the disadvantaged and the poverty-stricken. This is the Government that has seen an ongoing increase in pensions in real terms. This is the Government that has taken the initiative of introducing a family allowance supplement. These changes are welcomed by the whole community, especially by the tens of thousands of families who are benefiting.

I raise one aspect of these amendments that is being prostituted, misconstrued and distorted by the National Party in particular. I refer to a letter circulating throughout my own region written by the National Party State member for Broadsound, Denis Hinton. He refers to the 50 per cent rule, as it has become known, whereby the Government, following its changes in May last year, has sought to ensure that it recover moneys paid to people by way of lump sum compensation. This measure has been brought about, as the Minister for Social Security said, to try to stop double dipping, to try to ensure that those people who receive sickness benefits do not get paid again when they receive lump sum compensation, to make sure that those people who receive an economic loss component in their lump sum do not race immediately to the social security office and list themselves for the unemployment benefit. The member for Broadsound wrote to the unions in my area and sought their support in opposing the Federal Government's compensation recovery provisions, recently announced by the Federal Minister for Social Security. Mr Hinton says:

On 8 February 1988 Mr Howe announced a new rule, that 50 per cent of any lump sum workers compensation payment will be deemed to be for economic loss. Whereas previously 100 per cent was considered for economic loss now 50 per cent is utilised for income replacement.

Those statements are untrue. Mr Hinton is purposely distorting and misrepresenting the 50 per cent recovery policy. Not only is Mr Hinton, as a State member, doing that but so is the National Party throughout the nation. I imagine Liberal Party people are not missing the opportunity, either. The new rule is applied where lump sum compensation has been received since 9 February this year. The general principle is that 50 per cent of any lump sum compensation payment will be deemed to be for economic loss and therefore liable for compensatory recovery purposes unless otherwise specified in the lump sum determination. That might sound like double-dutch to a lot of people, but it means that when a person gets a lump sum compensation payment, if the determination or award does not specify the actual component for economic loss, the Social Security Department shall deem 50 per cent of that amount of money to be for economic loss. The consequences are that a person who receives that lump sum compensation will then not be eligible for unemployment benefit or any other government benefit during the period that that economic loss payment covered. Mr Hinton does not say it that way. He says that 50 per cent of any lump sum workers compensation payment will be deemed to be for economic loss. That is totally untrue. The 50 per cent rule applies only to voluntary settlements and consent orders. It does not apply to lump sum payments where the economic loss component is identified.

There is very good reason for the 50 per cent rule. The previous legislation required that the economic loss component of the lump sum compensation awards be identified. Honourable members will recall that in May last year we endeavoured to ensure that this amount of money could be recovered. This applies to workers compensation, motor vehicle accidents and the common law damages area. But this economic loss component is rarely identified. It was rarely identified before because clients, the insurers and their legal advisers were not willing to divulge the precise details of a settlement. In fact, often settlements have been couched in such vague and general terms so that no apportionment is evident and often the terms of settlement are written with the objective of escaping the recovery provisions of the legislation. The Government's hands and the hands of the Department of Social Security have been tied when trying to recover money because the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has decided in some cases that it is not open to the Department to go behind the terms of settlement to determine how much was for economic loss in the past and in the future. It is for this reason that the Government has had to act.

In a situation where a person has been on sickness benefits for, say, two years and has then received a $50,000 settlement, part of that is compensation for the two years. Surely any thinking person will agree that, if a person receives sickness benefits or some other government compensation or benefit during that two years, then that benefit ought to be repaid. I do not hear argument against that very often. The problem lies where a person receives, say, a lump sum settlement of $100,000 which includes payment for economic loss in the future. The Government is saying that, unless that settlement specifies or sets down particularly the component which is for economic loss, 50 per cent of that $100,000 is going to be deemed to be compensation for economic loss.

I cannot see that there is much difference in the types of cases that one could present here. If a person receives the government benefit on the one hand, he ought not then on the other hand to be compensated for that period during which he received the government benefit. If he receives a compensatory component for future economic loss, he ought not then be able to rush immediately into the unemployment office and get unemployment benefit for that loss period. Yet we have members of the National Party in particular running round and saying that we are taking the people's compensation.

Everyone realises that, if workers go on long service leave for X number of weeks, those workers do not have the right to go into the social security office or the Commonwealth Employment Service and go on the unemployment benefit. The reason is that they are receiving payment for that period. So, if a person has been injured and has been compensated for future economic loss-in other words, for inability to work during, say, the next couple of years-should that person be able get on unemployment benefit for that period? In principle, I say no.

The Government has been quite generous about this because instead of dividing by, say, the unemployment benefit that one would receive over that period, it is dividing by the average weekly earnings, which are $459.90. One works out a period when a person is ineligible by taking half the lump sum compensation payment and dividing it by $450.90, which results in a number of weeks of ineligibility. To put it in simple terms, if half the lump sum were $4,500 the recipient would not be able to receive unemployment benefit for approximately 10 weeks. I believe that is fair.

Mr Hinton says that every lump sum payment will be caught up in the system. That is simply not true. It is nonsense. This measure will apply only to unspecified settlements, only to those where the parties have come to agreement but have not set down the part, component or piece of that compensation that is for economic loss. It is worth noting also that a residual discretionary power resides with the Department under which in special circumstances the Department can disregard the whole or part of a lump sum for the purpose of the recovery provisions. In other words, if there are such circumstances, despite the fact that the settlement did not specify the economic loss, it is still possible to disregard totally the complete lump sum.

Mr Hinton, either in his typical ignorance or because he wants to be mischievous, is trying to attack the Federal Government and distort this proposal. I put it to him and to those opposite that if they are concerned about this proposal, if they are concerned particularly about workers' compensation, they should go back to the States. No-one in Queensland who receives a lump sum payment from the Workers Compensation Board will get caught up in this if the Workers Compensation Board is prepared to specify what the award is all about. If the Board is prepared to say that the payment of $25,000 has a medical cost component of so much, a compensation component for permanent injury or physical impairment of so much, a component for pain and suffering of so much and a component of so much for economic loss, only that small portion of economic loss is affected by this rule.

We need the facts and the truth to be made known. Right across this country people are crying out and saying, `The Government is taking away half of my compensation'. I know that in Queensland it has always been the rule that, if one received workers compensation followed by a lump sum benefit, those regular weekly or fortnightly benefits were subtracted from the lump sum. One was not allowed to have the benefits twice. What is the difference when the sickness or other Commonwealth benefit that one has received is subtracted from one's lump sum benefit or payment? The difference here is that in the past those who have been party to settlements have not been willing-for whatever reason-to specify the economic loss component. It is a problem that has faced the Government. It is a problem that has been facing many governments. But studies have shown very clearly that even under the 50 per cent rule most recipients will be better off. In fact, of 1,700 cases studied, 77 per cent showed workers compensation lump sums that had an economic component in excess of 50 per cent.

The rule that we are applying here is a fair one. It needs to be understood. It is not a simple concept, but it is fair and it is right in principle. If the taxpayers of this country pay people sickness benefits until they receive their lump sum payment, and if there is a component in that lump sum payment that compensates for past economic loss, surely the sickness benefits ought to be refunded or there ought to be some recovery of the moneys paid by the taxpayer. If the lump sum payment includes a component for future economic loss, surely if that is in lieu of wages or income lost, that person should not be able to get on the invalid pension or receive unemployment benefits during that set period.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—I am pleased to see that the honourable member for Franklin agrees with me. That is the principle. We are trying to reduce the heavy welfare burden on this nation while at the same time ensuring that the principles I enunciated earlier-that the policies are based on the needy, not the greedy-are implemented. We are trying to ensure that every Australian resident obtains adequate income support when and as he needs it. To achieve that we must be vigilant in ensuring that there is not a rip-off of the system.

SPEECH.PARA: I could give the House case after case in which people have received massive lump sum compensation payouts of $100,000 or $200,000 and virtually the next day have been able to go on an invalid pension, resulting in the taxpayer having to pay again. Case after case has been brought to my attention in which people have received government benefits up to the time when the compensation payment has been made. If that is the situation, surely those benefits ought to be repaid.

The Government is endeavouring to close loopholes by the amendments that are before the Parliament tonight. The Government has proved over and over again that it is a government of the people, a government prepared to overcome the problems of the disadvantaged. After all, we are the Government that introduced the first home owners scheme, which has helped something like 270,000 households. We are the Government that brought about the new child-care programs. This year alone there will be something like 110,000 child-care places. We have more than doubled, if not trebled, the numbers of places available under the Fraser Government. This is a government that has a special commitment, but the measures we bring in are not always explained clearly enough. I hope that honourable members will be able to go back to their electorates and explain exactly how this 50 per cent rule will work. When one first hears about it one thinks that something is wrong, that the people who have been suffering because of some injury or physical impairment are going to suffer again as the Government takes back all this money. But in principle the rule is correct: the taxpayers should not have to pay twice and there should not be double dipping.

TALK.START.PARA: —Terrible! Shocking!

SPEECH.PARA: If you are going to go around and take a census on whether every single child is going to be out of poverty-of course you are talking about an impossibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop sending cheerio messages to Toorak.

—I am talking about the Bill, which deals with social security. I have proved beyond any doubt that the standard of living of Australians is falling. I have warned the honourable member for Leichhardt that his seat will be lost and he should start planning his own retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to quote from a letter to the editor of the Age on 13 January under the heading `Young unemployed now get less training and less income'. It is written by Mr K. Disadvantaged young people have been left with a lack of employment, education and training options. The job search allowance leaves them with the worst option: no job and virtually no income.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Social Security Amendment Bill 1988, an omnibus Bill which rectifies a number of omissions or anomalies currently prevailing in the Act. Some of these anomalies, such as that dealing with the arrears of family allowance supplement and the continuity of the pension to the sole parent of a disabled child, are anomalies that I have personally encountered in dealing with my constituents. I congratulate the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) on his prompt addressing of these matters. As I said, they are minor amendments in terms of the entire Bill but are of immense importance to the individual Australian to whom they apply. While I support in principle the discontinuance of the supporting parent's benefit for parents whose youngest child has turned 16, in cases where the child is intellectually and/or physically disabled and cannot study or work full time it is only reasonable that the parent continue receiving this benefit with its fringe benefits. It is a very small change to the Act but a crucial one for the single parent of a disabled child.

SPEECH.PARA: The entire Bill is illustrative of the sensitivity and responsiveness of this Government to the welfare and income needs of the aged, unemployed and supporting parents. Honourable members will be aware that in the last four years or so about 200 significant social security policy changes have been put into effect. Many of these anomalies existed during the term of the previous Government, but nothing was done about them. The outstanding feature of the social security area in the last few years of the coalition Government was a huge blow-out in social security expenditure, not because of any improvement in the level of pensions- on the contrary, the real level of the age pension, for example, fell by 2 1/2 per cent in the seven years of conservative government. Nor was the blow-out due to any program or policy initiatives. As the Minister pointed out in the House last week, the social security blow-out under the previous Government was due to gross mismanagement of the social security system and of the economy as a whole.

By contrast, this Government has succeeded in reining in social security expenditure, and has done so partly by more effectively targeting groups and individuals who genuinely need assistance. The introduction of the assets test on age pensions means that wealthy people who had the means previously to convert income into assets can no longer claim the pension. We have introduced a work test for the unemployed so that only those who are genuinely in search of work are entitled to the benefit. We have tightened eligibility for supporting parents' and other benefits and tightened the checking of conditions for their receipt. As a consequence, many recipients of those benefits-people who are receiving them under false pretences or dishonestly-have had those benefits taken away.

At the same time as reining in social security expenditure as a whole, this Government has also introduced probably the most extensive and effective means ever in relieving poverty-that is, the family assistance package. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) said that the Opposition supports the family assistance package. It supports it, but it did not introduce it when it was in power. I venture to say that it could not introduce it under its present economic policy, such as it is, because the family assistance package on the scale that we are applying it is hardly consistent with $11 billion to $13 billion in spending cuts, which is what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has advocated at various times.

The Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill refers to a fall in living standards. It refers to this Government's policies causing a fall in living standards. No-one on this side of the House denies that there has been a fall in living standards. It has been a consequence of deliberate policies of wage restraint and reining in of government expenditure. Those measures were necessary in order to rectify some of the huge economic problems which this Government had to face, in large part as a result of the economic mismanagement of the previous Government. These measures of restraint which have hit the Australian population in such a difficult way are working. The economy is turning around so that from now on we can look at freeing up wages and at an improvement in living standards.

The eternal question, of course, is: what would the Opposition do? When the honourable member for Bradfield spoke in this debate earlier, my colleague the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) asked him what he or his Party would do about falling living standards. Did he tell us what he would do? Of course he did not, because he does not have a clue what he would do. He used that hoary old debating ploy which is normally used when someone does not know the answer to a question of turning the question around and asking what we are doing. He knows what we are doing. Among other things, we have introduced, as I have said, the family assistance package, which is the greatest single measure taken by any Australian government to assist low income families. The difference between the Australian Labor Party and the Opposition parties-and it needs to be pointed out sometimes to the Opposition-is that we are in government and they are in opposition. We do not have their luxury of talking about what should or should not happen. We cannot, as did the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) and the honourable member for Bradfield, recount those touching little vignettes about poor families that they have known and how terrible it is for them. We are expected to put our money where our mouth is and we do. We are introducing measures which go a long way towards alleviating poverty in this country. Until the Opposition can come up with some concrete policies and programs to address the problems that it chooses to identify, it certainly cannot be taken seriously.

The honourable member for Franklin gave what I thought was probably the most honest contribution to this debate from the other side of the House. He said that the Liberal and National parties in their time in government had big problems in the social security area. He said that the previous Government had had to untangle problems during its time in government. He did not actually say that any of the problems were caused by the policies or actions of that Government. His words were that all of a sudden there were single mothers and all of a sudden there was unemployment, as though these things just dropped down from heaven, and the previous Government's actions or policies had nothing to do, for example, with creating unemployment. He said that unemployment had not improved since Labor came to power. It has been said a million times, but I will say it gain: over one million jobs have been created since this Government came to power. That figure should be contrasted with the 186,900 jobs lost during the years of the Fraser-Howard Government. In September 1983 the unemployment rate in this country was 10.3 per cent. It is now 7.4 per cent. At that same time, in mid-1983, youth unemployment was 28 per cent. It is now 19.3 per cent-still too high, but certainly lower than it was. Certainly, this does not bear out the accusations of the honourable member for Franklin that this Government has done nothing about unemployment.

My colleague the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), who is at the table at the moment, has pointed out in his speeches that if the participation rate in the employment market were the same now as it was in 1983, unemployment would be 4.5 per cent. It would be down from 10.3 per cent to 4.5 per cent if the participation rate were the same. The participation rate is higher now because more people are in the job market, more people are looking for jobs, and particularly because women in this country are now joining the labour force. They now have the opportunity to find jobs and to choose what they will do-much more so than they did before.

That brings me to the comments made by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton), who bemoaned the fact that these days, apparently, some wives and mothers find themselves in a position where they have to work. They do not really want to work, but because of economic circumstances they have to work. I have heard this argument many times. I will not even bother to try to go through the argument that some men actually work for money, too. Let us not always assume that the husband has to be the main income earner, the breadwinner, and the wife's salary is always a kind of supplementary thing that she earns for pin money to send the kids to private schools. Let us talk about one income families, two income families or families with one and a half incomes. Let us not always assume that the husbands and fathers will be the main income earner and that wives generally only work because the husband is not bringing in enough money.

One point which the Opposition has raised recently is that Social Security offices in most States are now closing for half a day a week. I think it was the Liberal Senator Amanda Vanstone who put out a Press release asking the Minister to explain why this was happening. I think she implied that this was some sort of dereliction of duty and that the public was not being adequately served. I said earlier that in the last few years 200 significant policy changes have been put into effect in the social security area. That obviously means that staff have been under great pressure to come to grips with those changes and to apply those changes. Because of applications for new programs and new moneys, such as the family assistance package, there has been a tremendous backlog in paperwork and processing. The staff of the Social Security offices, the unions involved, the Department and the Minister have got together and very sensibly decided that the best way to serve the interests of the public is to close the office to the walk-in public for one afternoon a week.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with rostering?

—I do not see what rostering has to do with it. That will not reduce the total amount of work. Rostering will not cut down the backlog. Perhaps the honourable member thinks that more staff should be engaged; that that may be the way to get around it. They are closing the office for half a day a week to the walk-in public in order that they can undertake training and acquaint themselves with the 200 changes that have taken place in the Social Security Act in the last few years. Emergency arrangements are still maintained. Closures have come into force only after considerable consultation, as I said, with the unions involved, with the staff and with welfare agencies in the local areas of each Social Security office. The switchboard in those offices will still operate on those afternoons so that anyone who rings in can still get some sort of service. For the Opposition to imply that there is some sort of inefficiency or even some sort of dereliction of duty on the part of social security staff is a slight on the dedication, hard work and commitment that, in my experience, the vast majority of social security staff in Social Security offices, and particularly at the coal face at the counters, display. I reject the Opposition's amendment and urge the House to support the Bill.
