As a matter of fact, the honourable member for Hawker said that she thought it was a favourite ploy of the Opposition when challenged to ask something to avoid the question by turning it back on the Government. I wonder whether I have ever heard a better illustration of just what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is about day in and day out in this House.

The honourable member for Hawker said that one great luxury the Opposition enjoys is that because it is in Opposition it can just talk; it never has to deliver the goods. Let me remind the honourable member for Hawker that no-one sits on this side of the House without intending to occupy the government benches and then be immediately accountable. If that is not illustration enough, let me remind the honourable member for Hawker of just what the Prime Minister was about when in the July 1986 election he had the sheer barefaced audacity to be so cruel, knowing that he could not deliver, as to say that by 1990 no Australian child would be living in poverty. He knew, we knew and Australia knew that that could be nothing but empty words, that the promise could never be delivered. The accusation made by the honourable member for Hawker and levelled at the Opposition is groundless because it is precisely the tactic used by her own Prime Minister as an election ploy. He was prepared, frankly, to offer up as a sacrifice to the people of Australia the children living in poverty.

It has been almost indecent to sit and listen to the debate that has raged tonight on the social security amendments. One could be forgiven for presuming that all compassion had been vested in the Government benches and was solely on the other side of the House. This has been a debate where the image projected into the gallery and to any of the community listening has been that this is a them and us debate and that the measure of compassion in Australian society is the measure of what we, the people of the Parliament, do with the taxpayers' money. Once again I remind the people of this Parliament and of the nation that what we do with the taxpayers' money has little, if anything, to do with compassion. Real compassion is not measured by what we do with taxpayers' money; that is never actually ours to spend. We acquire it; they do not give it to us. We demand it; they do not volunteer it. Real compassion is measured by what we do with our own resources. That is the real measure of compassion. We are here as nothing more than the stewards of the resources that the taxpayers of Australia have unwillingly made available to us. The difference across this Parliament on this debate tonight is not a difference in degree of care but a difference in degree of responsibility. In 1988 the truth, relative to the social security debate, is that if a person fathers or mothers a child he or she must assume responsibility for that child. No responsibility will be endowed upon him or her as acute as that responsibility for his or her own flesh and blood. Parenting is not a role that can be duplicated by the Government. With the best will in the world the Government cannot provide some sort of substitute parenting role.

To take up the points made by the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) earlier in this debate, we have the quandary where a single parent earning the same income as a two-parent family will find himself or herself entitled to more in the way of benefits. We find that a less than ideal situation. His plea, my plea and the plea of all members on this side of the House is not for less compassion, less care, but for a comprehensive family policy that does not disadvantage those who grow up in what we would loosely call normal families. What has been behind the Opposition's debate is that we do not in any sense want to be less compassionate or to deny resources to people in real need, but we do want to resist the emergence of a nanny state. I use that term because, if ever a nanny state applied, it applies to this debate in that a nanny effectively is a substitute parent.

If I am to deal tonight with the question of poverty and poverty as it affects Australian families, I cannot resist the temptation to bring to the Government's attention the real focus of poverty in our nation. The truth is that, whilst most people merely presume that poverty-and poverty as addressed by the legislation currently before the House-exists in urban Australia, in fact real poverty exists in rural Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—An honourable member says that that is rubbish. Let me refer him to a recent study by Mr Bruce Mackenzie, a senior lecturer at the Warrnambool Institute of Technology, and Dr Jim Lees, Director of the Rural Development Centre at the University of New England. It is not a Liberal Party document; it is not a National Party document. Mr Mackenzie and Dr Lees discovered that, of the 37 poorest electorates in Australia, 33 are in rural areas and only four are in the cities. Furthermore, they found that 76 per cent of Australian families who are earning less than $12,000 a year are rural dwellers.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand why the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) is listening attentively to my statistics. His electorate and mine are directly affected by these statistics. We have the classic case of poverty being vested in rural Australia and the legislation before the House is currently targeted towards urban Australia. Before he in any sense disagrees with that statement, let me ask him-and it is pertinent to ask the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), who is at the table, as well-in regard to the existence of poverty in rural Australia, in areas of South Australia represented by the honourable member for Grey and me, why Dr Cornwall, the State Minister for Health, intends to deny people in the towns of Laura and Blyth, the home town of the honourable member for Adelaide, might I digress to add--

TALK.START.PARA: —And Tailem Bend.

—And Tailem Bend in the electorate of the honourable member for Barker. Why does the State Minister intend to deny people in the poorest electorates that fundamental right to some sort of adequate health care?
—Tailem Bend is a railway town.

—Exactly. We heard the honourable member for Capricornia in his own particularly evangelical way talk about the special consideration this Government has for poor people. In the face of my statistics I ask him to substantiate that sort of claim. The truth is that while the Government claims to have a particular concern for poverty in this nation, no-one can escape-not even by the convenient statistics used by the honourable member for Hawker-the truth that the rise in government expenditure under this Government has been $30 billion. Thirty billion dollars has been taken away from the taxpayers of Australia and vested in the Parliament. The only defence we heard from the honourable member for Canning was that, in the process, the Government managed to locate 12 millionaires who happened to be on the pension. Is that the real measure of what this Government is about?

SPEECH.PARA: In the half decade since 1983 we have faced-and the Government acknowledges this fact; let us be fair-declining living standards, increasing queues for houses, as the shadow minister for housing and public administration, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), could well and truly substantiate, and a real tax burden such as we have not seen before on middle Australia. The Opposition has indicated that it is prepared to support the Government's initiatives but we have moved an amendment to make the debate that much more honest by focusing on the Government's shortfalls. I regret that in this debate, in which we have indicated support for the Government's initiatives, Government speakers have chosen to divide the House down the middle and create a `them and us' mentality. It is little wonder that the electorate is so cynical about the exercises we go on with in this place. When we consider both the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bradfield and the statement made by the Prime Minister in the 1986 election campaign, when he frankly promised--

TALK.START.PARA: —We did not have an election in 1986.

—In 1987, I beg your pardon. The Prime Minister had the audacity to promise what he knew he could not deliver in terms of ridding children in Australia of poverty. It is little wonder that the electorate is as cynical as it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was somewhat amused by the contribution from the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), as I am sure were all those who were listening. I do not know what books he has been reading. I do not know whether he has been reading Phantom comics or Donald Duck. I am not certain what his source has been for the information which he has given to the House, but he certainly has not been looking at the facts. He certainly has not been examining the record of this Government. He certainly does not understand the commitment this Government has to social justice. I will come to that point later. I want to expose the Opposition members for what they are. They are an empty-headed lot who will sink to the lowest levels to try to deny those people most in need their rightful place in our community. It does the Opposition no credit at all to move amendments such as the fatuous amendment which has been moved by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). I will return to this matter during my address.

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security Amendment Bill, as previous speakers have suggested, plays a major part in this Government's strategy on social justice. The most significant aspects of this Bill will amend the Act as outlined in the explanatory memorandum accompanying the Bill. It states:
The Bill would amend the Act-
to make minor changes to Family Allowance Supplement (FAS) in the following manner:
-Apportion advance lump sum leave payments as income over the period of leave;
-treat lump sum payments for termination of employment as having been received on the last day of employment;
-apportion arrears of educational allowances over the period covered by the payment;

Amongst other things, it makes minor changes to the job search allowance by excluding children of pensioners and beneficiaries from the operation of the parental income test. I am sure that the Opposition supports the guts of these proposals. The debating points that have been raised by the honourable member for Bradfield ought to be treated with the irreverence they deserve. This Government has been attempting to rationalise its expenditure on social security and it has done that in a number of ways. One of the most important ways in which this has been done is by addressing the needs of people in remote Australia.

I notice that the honourable member for Wakefield has left the House. That is unfortunate because I am now in a position to address a couple of matters he raised. One matter is the approach the Department of Social Security has developed, after long consultation and discussion within the Department, as a result of input from outside sources, to a North Australian Development Unit (NADU). This is a very important development in terms of the administration of social security in northern Australia. The remote northern parts of Australia are so different from the rest of the country that to meet the Department's charter an enterprising approach to both the development of policies and the delivery of services is warranted. This reflects the need for real world input to help the Department to design policy practices and systems which will efficiently deliver social security programs to people living in outback Australia.

The North Australian Development Unit is a proposal which bases a policy making unit in Darwin. Its purpose is to concentrate on the development of policies and strategies to improve the applicability and delivery of departmental programs and services to people living in northern Australia. The Unit's activities are not limited to the Northern Territory; they also span the Pilbara and the Kimberleys in Western Australia and north-western and northern Queensland.

The Unit has three main areas of responsibility. They are: the development of ideas relating to the provision and improvement of departmental services in remote areas; the development of policy on matters specifically related to Aboriginal clients; and the development of policy on matters related to other groups of clients more commonly found in remote Australia, isolated outback communities and itinerant people. It provides one focal point for relevant divisions in the central office of the Department of Social Security to obtain comment and input into legislative and policy change and into system change proposals for remote area payment delivery. It will also be in a position to assist in the evaluation of new technology and to improve service delivery to remote area clients.

The North Australian Development Unit relates closely to three area offices in two State administrations. NADU not only fills the void which exists with the advent of area administration in the Northern Territory but also adds substantially to the effectiveness of current activities by providing a north Australian perspective and by bringing consistency into service delivery across Western Australia's north-west, the Northern Territory and northern Queensland. The staffing of NADU has been established as a central office outpost with responsibility for the Unit ultimately resting with the national manager of field services within the Department. The director of the Unit has supervisory responsibilities for the Unit's staff and program, with the Northern Territory office providing necessary services.

The key staff of the Unit at present in Darwin are Mr Joe Flick, an Aboriginal man from New South Wales, and Mr Ian Shortell, and the person with whom they are working in Canberra is Mr Gwyn Hurry. Their work is very important and I was pleased to announce the development of this Unit at the opening of the new Department of Social Security office at Casuarina in Darwin some time ago. The following projects are an indication of the types of issues that the Unit will deal with. They relate primarily to the delivery of services in remote areas, as I suggested earlier.

I refer first to the payment system of the Department. Historically, the standard payment systems have not provided reliable or effective means of supplying income maintenance to remote clients. The relationship between standard systems, including direct credits and cheque payments and specialist payment systems such as out of area unemployment benefit, and community payment systems should be reviewed and rationalised. Outstations proliferate throughout the Northern Territory and northern Australia, as the honourable member for Bradfield would know, and a service strategy needs to be developed to cater for the servicing of Aboriginal outstations, many of which are becoming more isolated as tribal groups move to remote localities. Most outstations are difficult to reach and seldom have any telecommunications infrastructure that would assist in the timely assessment and delivery of social security payments.

In terms of information dissemination, the challenge of providing timely and accurate information in a form that can be readily understood by clients living in remote areas has in the past been accepted by the Northern Territory Administration. However, although a number of initiatives have been attempted, most have fallen by the wayside because of the lack of support and expertise that was available to the Administration. The accepted modus operandi of intensive review teams evolved and developed in an environment substantially different from that existing in northern Australia. Practices will need to be revised to take account of the remoteness, low population density and the different employment infrastructure of northern Australia. This will ensure that resources dedicated to this function are deployed effectively.

Forms design is a very basic requirement. I am sure the honourable member for Bradfield and some of the honourable members opposite will understand this, although I doubt the capacity of others. There is a need for input into the design of departmental forms from personnel who have a sound appreciation of the working arrangements in remote northern Australia. Some forms will need to be adapted to allow for the special conditions that apply to the servicing of remote localities. Forms need to be designed both to facilitate operational arrangements and to be understood by clients. Forms must also facilitate the sensitive delivery of services to remote area clients, the majority of whom are Aboriginal people.

I cannot overemphasise the importance of those developments. My experience in the area was that in 1978 I worked with Dr H. C. `Nugget' Coombs and Dr Maria Brandl on a project which was sponsored by the Department of Social Security through the then Minister, Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. The purpose of this project was to examine the impact of government programs on traditional Aboriginal communities, specifically in the area of socialisation of their children. It was a broad-ranging research project which culminated in the production of a book called A Certain Heritage, which I suggest the honourable member for Bradfield and the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and other Opposition members should read because they may learn a lot about people who live in remote communities and the need for the sorts of developments that this Government is now addressing.

It was a far-reaching research document. My particular area of interest, apart from looking at education services in remote communities, was the community development employment project, which was a product of the Fraser Government. I am glad to say that the project is now proliferating throughout northern Australia and there is a great deal of demand from Aboriginal communities to come within the scheme. I point out to honourable members opposite and others who might be listening that the community development employment project scheme is the only one of its type in Australia. Effectively, it means that Aboriginal people forgo unemployment benefits for the sake of accepting a similar amount of money with an add-on administrative component of some 40 per cent to work for money which they would otherwise be entitled to as unemployment benefit recipients.

The policy issues relating to servicing remote areas include, among other things, Australian Law Reform Commission reports. Appropriate policies relating to the findings of the Australian Law Reform Commission in the area of Aboriginal traditional law and culture need to be developed. Specific issues include polygamous marriages, changes in child custody, under-age marriage and others. Also, there needs to be an examination of the definition of unemployment. There is a need to clarify the application of section 116 of the Social Security Act, which refers to the work test, to client groups within the northern area.

The advantages of the North Australian Development Unit should be obvious to all but some of the advantages, for those who might have some sort of myopic vision, are that it will achieve one consolidated and consistent approach to remote areas issues, thus overcoming approaches across the three administrations that have often been at variance with each other; provide greater opportunities to assemble departmental experts in a concentrated way to achieve solutions to remote area problems quickly; provide better targeting or prioritising of departmental service delivery activities in remote areas; provide better long term planning to achieve solutions to current problems facing the Department in the delivery of services to remote areas; and provide development opportunities for staff to work in remote localities and later to apply this knowledge to other operations within the Department.

Again, I cannot overemphasise how important these developments are in rationalising and improving the efficiency of the delivery of social security services in northern Australia. They will, in the fullness of time, lead to the more efficient delivery of service and the addressing of some of the more fundamental problems that occur in northern Australia, particularly in relation to poverty, to which the amendment from the honourable member for Bradfield refers. The honourable member for Bradfield would be very cognisant of the high level of poverty that exists within northern Australia, particularly among Aboriginal constituents, and the need for special methods of delivery of service to those clients which are cognisant of the cultural needs and aspirations of Aboriginal Australians as well as taking into account the administrative efficacy of Department of Social Security procedures and the need for financial accountability.

I turn to the erroneous amendment which has been moved by the honourable member for Bradfield. He states that he deplores the Hawke Government's performance in the area of poverty and in economic and social policies, in terms of social justice. I refer shortly to the second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) which was delivered by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly). She said:

There is no area which more fundamentally shows the difference in approach between this Labor Government and the conservative opposition . . . When in government the conservatives proved themselves incapable of this form of development.
The Minister referred to some of the policy initiatives that the Opposition is well known for, and said:

they would terminate eligibility for sole parent pensions when the youngest child turns 10; they would make people who resign a job wait for six months before paying any benefit; they would not pay benefit to people who are sacked for lengthy periods, not until their redundancy payments are exhausted.

Last year this Labor Government introduced a family allowance supplement as part of our attack on child poverty. I would like now to address the question of families. Under the previous Government, the real disposable incomes of low income families declined by 5.5 per cent for a beneficiary couple with four children and 4.2 per cent for a sole parent pensioner with children. As a result, the number of children in poverty more than doubled under the previous Government, while at the same time additional pension or benefits for children fell by about 32 per cent in real terms between 1975 and 1976, and 1982 and 1983. The value of this payment has been increased by about 59 per cent in real terms since this Government came to power, or by 102 per cent for children aged 13, 14 or 15.

While the Government has concentrated on improving assistance for low income families, other families have benefited from three rounds of income tax cuts made since March 1983. For example, for the benefit of those opposite, a single taxpayer with no dependants, earning $200 a week, will have gone from paying $34 tax a week in March 1983 to $25 a week in July 1987. A taxpayer earning $400 a week will have gone from paying $98 a week to $83 a week. That illustrates well the performance of this Government in the area of social justice in addressing the areas of poverty and need in this community.

I would like to mention a couple of other areas, one of which is the area of child care. I heard the honourable member for Wakefield wax lyrical about matters related to a nanny state. Let us talk about a nanny state and the abysmal child care record of the Opposition when it was in government. At the end of the current strategy to create 20,000 new child care places this Labor Government will have increased the number of child care places by some 150 per cent since taking office. Since 1983 the number of places has increased from 46,000-for the benefit of the honourable member for Bradfield-to 110,000 places, which will be operational by December 1988. Let me remind the honourable member for Wakefield of the pitiful amount of money the Opposition spent on child care during 1982 and 1983 when it was in government-only $62m. In 1987-88 this Government will expend some $229m on child care. So much for the claims of the Opposition, and the honourable member for Bradfield in particular.

But I will not finish there. Let us talk about the veterans community. Let us give further lie to the fatuous claims being made by the Opposition. Since 1983 allocations to the Veterans' Affairs portfolio have increased from $2.5 billion to $4.3 billion. The rate of service pensions paid to single pensioners has risen from 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings in 1983 to the current level of 24.6 per cent. In 1987-88 expenditure on compensation and income support and the administration of those services increased by 13.6 per cent over that in the previous year. Pension rates are indexed twice-yearly.

In addition, in the area of veterans affairs, a major program of public works totalling $92m over the past five years has continued the expansion, modernisation and improvement of the repatriation hospital system and ensures the delivery of quality health care to the veteran community. Amongst other things, highlights of that program include the replacement of operating theatres at the Concord Repatriation Hospital, costing $18.4m. The care of aged and infirm beneficiaries has been enhanced by the establishment of age and extended care units in all States to assess patients and refer them to the most appropriate form of treatment or care. The list goes on.

Before I conclude I would like to address some of the measures we could expect from the Opposition if it were in government. I would like to refer to the document released by the Business Council of Australia on 17 April which has been so warmly applauded by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), in respect of which he said that the $3.5 billion cuts which had been advanced through the Business Council of Australia did not go deep enough. What we are seeing is a repeat by the Opposition of the Thatcherite approach, which has left millions in poverty in the United Kingdom. The conservative parties in the United Kingdom have recognised that the poor will suffer and will continue to suffer under their monetarist policies. Let me quote from the Business Council of Australia document. It says:
Spending cuts must affect some people adversely.

If one looks at this heinous document one finds out who those spending cuts will most affect. Let us turn to the part of the document which addresses the question of social security. I repeat that the shadow Treasurer warmly endorsed this document. I wonder whether the honourable member for Bradfield also endorses it. Let us see whether he will debate with the Business Council of Australia what the Opposition would do to the poor of this country. Amongst other things, it says that it will abolish the family allowance and increase the income tested family allowance supplement to $32 a week, which will save $100m. Where will that come from? It will come from the mouths of the most poverty stricken people in this nation. Alternatively, it will lower the income test for family allowance which it reckons will save $100m. Then it will have a go at children's services programs. Let the honourable member for Wakefield address the questions which are raised in this document. The document states:
Children's services programs have grown very rapidly.

The Opposition intends to save $10m by privatising them. The Opposition does not care about those people in the community who cannot afford privatised child care. The Opposition has demonstrated once again, as it continues to do, that it does not care. It is to its eternal shame that it moves these empty-headed, fatuous amendments to positive Government programs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberals had so little understanding of public housing that before the New South Wales election they promised that they would sell off public housing at discount prices. As we told them before the election, that was in contravention of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Now that they have been elected they have backed off that outrageous policy. They have quickly realised that they have to act more responsibly and not make statements that do not stand up.

Firstly, there is the family allowance supplement. The honourable member for Bradfield said that all we have done has been to come up with the family allowance supplement. As many of my colleagues have said, the family allowance supplement is one of the greatest breakthroughs for working families that any government has come up with. Already more than 200,000 children in families are on the family allowance supplement. The average payments are in the range of $40 to $60 a week, that is, extra tax-free payments-and the honourable member for Bradfield says that all we have done has been to come up with the family allowance supplement! But the Opposition has to support it because it is so good.

Another area is child support, child maintenance, which the Opposition also has to support, even though it has tried to minimise the enormous breakthrough that has been for families and for children in Australia. The other area that has to be mentioned is the social justice strategy of this Government. I ask Opposition members whether they support it. What we are trying to do in government is to understand the causes of poverty, the reasons for poverty and the means to alleviate and get rid of it. That is why we set up the social security review, the first review of the social security system for 40 years-to get rid of the myths, to analyse the problems and to propose new directions. As a result we set goals. We set ourselves goals such as getting all Australian children out of poverty-and what does the Opposition do? The Opposition ridicules our goals. I conclude my comments by explaining very quickly what the social justice strategy means. Essentially it means fairness in the distribution of social power and resources; equity-fairness in the distribution of economic resources and political power; equality-the notion of equal, effective and comprehensive rights for all people, including civil, legal and industrial rights; access-which means fair and equal access to essential services such as health, education and housing; and participation-which means the opportunity to participate fully in personal development, social and community life and decision making. That is the social justice strategy which this Government has and which this Government is about to implement. It is a strategy the Opposition will never understand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond first to the two points the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) made which are relevant to the Social Security Amendment Bill. The honourable member indicated that the Opposition will closely monitor the operation of the changes we are making to compensation recovery provisions. Of course I welcome that. This is a complex area in which there has been widespread collusion to avoid the operation of the provisions of the Social Security Act. The honourable member for Bradfield also referred to the treatment of German restitution payments for pension income test purposes. He asserted that the Government's amendment is defective because it could be interpreted as continuing to subject to income test the restitution payments for loss of earning capacity, and will not exempt those parts of German pension received by reason of deemed contributions under the restitution laws.

SPEECH.PARA: On the first point, the Opposition's first amendment, to clause 3 (a), would provide that only German restitution payments expressed to be for loss of wages and salaries would be included as income for the purposes of the Social Security Act. The Opposition's concern about the existing words `expressed to be paid for lost income' is apparently that they could encompass payments which are variously described as `loss of professional advancement', `loss of career' and `loss of earning capacity'. This concern is misplaced. As a matter of legal interpretation, those payments represent capital losses and are not within the description `lost income'.

The essential point about the Bill is that it relates to payments expressed to be for loss of income. Payments which are not identified in the German documents expressly as being for loss of income will not be subject to the income test. The Opposition has legal advice from my office on this point. It also has the draft guidelines for the operation of this clause. I make it clear that payments not expressly identified as being for loss of income will not be regarded as income. The proposed Opposition amendment is indeed unduly restrictive. It excludes payments covering lost business or investment or superannuation income, and these are no different in character from payments for lost wages or salaries. Two points need to be made concerning the second objection of the Opposition. Firstly, for those pensions which would be affected by the Bill as it is drafted the Opposition amendment would make no difference. Secondly, what is the Opposition's rationale for arguing that a proportion of a pension not paid as restitution but paid as a pension should be excluded from income tests?

I go on to the honourable member for Bradfield's dissertation on the nature of poverty. He asserted, correctly, that the level of money received by a family unit is not an accurate measure of poverty. He told the House that poverty is the inability to utilise services such as education, an inability to get employment, or an inability to obtain maintenance. He asserted that not understanding this had caused the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to make a fundamental error. Let me assure the House that the Prime Minister made no such error. He and this Government understand precisely the nature of poverty, and it is precisely as the honourable member for Bradfield described it.

Let us look at the record of this Government in ensuring that Australian families get access to the quality services they need-for example, Medicare. There is no more terrible poverty than the inability to obtain necessary quality health care, the inability to take a sick child to the doctor one trusts and to be sure that the child will be examined and treated in a professional and a quality way. Medicare guarantees this to every Australian family. Compare the policy of the Opposition, which would abolish community rating, require people to insure privately and fine those who fail to do so. Its policy would deny to all those low wage families that it is concerned about access to decent quality medical care.

One of the great differences between poverty as it exists within this country and, for example, poverty in the United States is that in the United States the absence of anything equivalent to Medicare means that low income people are trapped in poverty in a way that certainly is not the case in Australia. In the United States once someone moves off what they describe as the welfare system or welfare benefits into the work force then they are immediately vulnerable to health costs in a way that low income people in Australia are not. It is not simply that Medicare provides a safety net; it also assists people to make with some security the transition from dependence on social security payments to the work force without the fear that they will be exposed to significant health costs or alternatively have to run the risk of injury or illness resulting in their being driven very quickly back into poverty.

Another example of the Government's commitment to achieve higher levels of real income for people on low incomes in Australia, people living within ordinary Australian working families, is the child care program, which I think has been one of the outstanding features of this Government's commitment to social welfare. The honourable member for Bradfield would know the difficulties faced by sole parent families and other low income families trying to get access to employment when child care is not available. Again the Opposition's policy is clear; that is, it would abolish funding for child care.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Our policy is clear and consistent. We will continue to expand the availability of quality child care places for all Australian families. The honourable member for Bradfield made the intelligent interjection, `Rubbish!'. SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 2, lines 21 and 22, omit ``(other than an amount expressed to be paid for lost income)'', substitute ``(other than an amount expressly to be paid for lost wages or salary)''.

The effect of the amendment is to clarify beyond any reasonable doubt the impact on those who receive restitution payments from the German Government for war crimes committed against them during the nazi era and the capacity of those people to be protected from the loss of income due to the application of the income test which currently falls on retirement incomes. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) made it perfectly clear in his remarks at the end of the second reading debate that the Government does not wish to accept our amendment.

I will put to the chamber the simple facts. The Minister issued a Press statement on 30 November 1987, following discussions which he had had with the Federation of Australian Jewish Welfare Societies and the Executive Vice-President of the Federation, Mr Walter Lippmann, which read:
In 1985 Mr Howe announced that German restitution payments for loss of income are taken into account under pension income tests, and that all other restitution payments would be disregarded.
`I have asked the Department today to make sure that this policy is applied in all cases . . .
Administration of these provisions has clearly been confused over the past year.
`This confusion causes unnecessary concern to pensioners getting restitution payments, and difficulties for the Department in administering the income tests.
He finalised the Press statement by saying:
`The Social Security Act will be amended to make clear that the policy I announced in 1985 should apply in all cases . . .

The simple facts are that the legal advisers to the relevant Australian Jewish welfare societies are not satisfied that the proposed amendment will, as he said, apply in all cases. It is precisely because of that that I have moved:
Clause 3, page 2, lines 21 and 22, omit ``(other than an amount expressed to be paid for lost income)', substitute `(other than an amount expressly to be paid for lost wages or salary)'.

In my contribution to the second reading debate I emphasised the fact that the history of the effect on income-whether it be wages or salaries-of numerous, principally Jewish, persons who suffered grievously as a result of the Holocaust, whether they were actually incarcerated in concentration camps or elsewhere, is well documented.

The fact of the matter is that some thousands of people in Australia live in fear that unless the Act is adequately amended they will constantly face the difficulties of bureaucratic decisions in the future being made on the basis of the Government's proposed amendment which they believe is not explicit enough specifically in relation to those payments for lost wages or salaries. The Minister happens to be basically correct in his interpretation of the impact of the German restitution arrangements, but that is really not the issue. The issue is the interface between the basis of those payments and how they are taken into account in relation to Australian social security regulations.

There are a group of people who came under the Reichversicherung rules. They would have been working in Germany between 1933 and 1939. During that period in which they were in the German work force they automatically had sums deducted from their salaries by the German Government on the basis of essentially compulsory superannuation levies. As a result of the nazi restitution legislation of 1949, some of these people are eligible for entitlements, but the Government's proposed amendment will still be interpreted as loss of income in those cases. All we are trying to suggest in this amendment in all good faith is to put in those additional words which emphasise that we are talking about loss of wages or salaries. It does not take account of the other payments which may be made as part of the total restitution package, but there is confusion over those two issues.

He also ignores the fact that it was his Government and its man, Mr Murphy, and his changes to the Family Law Act which had the effect of bringing hundreds of thousands more parents and children into a situation where families in this society broke down. All I can say in reply to the remarks he has thrown around tonight suggesting that his shadow Minister, for example, crawls around the welfare lobby is that if I were not there he would be complaining. The very people that Government members come into the chamber today crying about being in distress are in distress principally because they do not have employment. Time after time in this Parliament and elsewhere they came forward to support the most outrageous demands for terms and conditions of employment which today have meant a reaping of the most inevitable result of all; that is, that employers have replaced labour with capital. Sadly, the major area of job loss has been where people need the maximum support. The Whitlam Government brought in policies which overnight, with 25 per cent tariff reductions, cut out hundreds of thousands of jobs. Labor parties here have tried to run this country on the whim of an idea without ever bothering to see what effect it has on ordinary men and women, those same people who were stupid enough for so long to believe that as a Labor party honourable members stood for compassion and concern. They are facing their Armageddon and the sooner it comes the better.

Senate amendment-
Page 6, clause 7, proposed subsection 32 (2), lines 10 and 11, leave out the proposed subsection, insert the following subsection:
`(2) A person shall not be appointed under paragraph (1) (b) unless the relevant authority and the relevant staff organisation have first agreed that the person is suitable for appointment.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendment be agreed to.

This is a very simple amendment. The Bill has passed the Senate with this one amendment, an amendment that the Government supported in the Senate at the behest of the Australian Democrats. Instead of requiring union consent to the appointment of a person other than the chairperson to a joint selection committee which considers promotions the Bill has been amended by the Senate so that a person shall not be promoted to a joint selection committee unless management and the union first agree that the person is suitable for appointment. It is not the original position of the Government. It is not the original position of the Opposition. It is a half-way house. I hope that it is something on which we can all find agreement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to go back to the debate on this Bill on 22 February. At that time the Opposition said that it was not happy with clause 7, which we thought would leave applicants open to discrimination and which we then proposed to amend. In the committee stage we emphasised that the clause that offended us was proposed new section 32, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A person shall not be appointed under paragraph (1) (b) unless the relevant staff organisation consents to the appointment of that person.

In every respect the motion we were then moving sought to amend that. Our present motion-one would need a lawyer to find the difference-states that a person shall not be appointed under paragraph (1) (b) unless the relevant authority and the relevant staff organisation have first agreed that the person is suitable for appointment. It extends the agreement required to the relevant staff organisation. We would have liked the government to take notice at the time. I remember that the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) was a new Minister at that stage and he was determined not to let anybody get under his guard. It just goes to show that at times if the Government listened to the wisdom and the amendments of the Opposition it would not find itself in this situation. We do not really believe the legislation goes as far as we would want it to and, as I have just said, I suggest that the Government at times should wait a while and look at the amendments we propose.
